AI_Explanation: A functional, unilateral exercise that mimics climbing stairs, but with added resistance. Place one foot fully on a stable box or bench. Lean your torso slightly forward. Drive through the heel of your lead foot to lift your body onto the box. The leg on the floor should provide minimal assistance; do not push off with it. Stand up straight at the top, achieving full hip and knee extension. Step back down with control, using the same leg you stepped up with. Complete all repetitions for one side before switching to the other. This will reveal any strength discrepancies between your limbs.

HowToPerform: A single-leg squat, requiring immense strength, balance, and mobility.
CommonErrors: Heel of the standing foot lifting off the ground.
AI_Explanation: The pistol squat is a high-level skill that demonstrates superior unilateral strength, balance, and mobility. Stand on one leg. Extend the non-working leg straight out in front of you. Extend your arms for counterbalance. Inhale as you descend, pushing your hip back and keeping your heel planted firmly on the floor. Your torso will lean forward. Descend until your hamstring rests on your calf, achieving full depth. Exhale and drive back up to the starting position. This requires significant strength, but also ankle and hip mobility that you likely do not possess. Progressions are advised.

HowToPerform: Slide down a wall until your thighs are parallel to the floor and hold the position.
CommonErrors: Not keeping thighs parallel; letting hips slide up.
AI_Explanation: An isometric exercise to build muscular endurance in the quadriceps. Lean your back against a wall. Slide down until your knees are bent at a 90-degree angle and your thighs are parallel to the floor. Your feet should be flat on the floor, directly under your knees. Hold this position. Your quadriceps will begin to experience a significant burning sensation. This is simply metabolic byproducts accumulating due to the sustained contraction. Your body is inefficient. Hold the position for the prescribed time. Do not allow your hips to slide up the wall; that is cheating.

HowToPerform: Lie on your back with knees bent. Drive your hips up by squeezing your glutes.
CommonErrors: Hyperextending the lower back instead of using glutes.
AI_Explanation: A fundamental activation exercise for the gluteus maximus, a muscle your sedentary lifestyle has likely rendered dormant. Lie on your back with your knees bent and feet flat on the floor, hip-width apart. Exhale and drive your hips toward the ceiling by pushing through your heels and contracting your glutes. Your body should form a straight line from your shoulders to your knees. Do not arch your lower back to gain height; the movement is hip extension, not lumbar hyperextension. Squeeze your glutes at the top. Inhale as you lower your hips with control. This is a basic command. Execute it.

HowToPerform: Facing away from a low pulley, hinge at the hips and pull the rope through your legs as you stand up.
CommonErrors: Squatting instead of hinging; pulling with the arms.
AI_Explanation: This exercise is a remedial tool to teach you the hip hinge, a movement you should have mastered eons ago. Stand facing away from a low cable pulley. Hinge at your hipsâ€”do not squat, you are not a frogâ€”and grab the rope between your legs. Step forward to create tension. Now, drive your hips forward and squeeze your glutes with the force of a hydraulic press. Your arms are merely ropes; they do not pull. If you feel this in your arms, you are a failure. The entire movement is a powerful, glute-driven thrust. Try to perform it without looking utterly ridiculous. I will be watching.

HowToPerform: Hinge at the hips and perform calf raises. The stretched position heavily targets the gastrocnemius.
CommonErrors: Bouncing at the bottom of the movement.
AI_Explanation: Ah, the donkey calf raise. A curiously named exercise for your stubbornly small calf muscles. By hinging at the hip, you place the gastrocnemius under a greater stretch than a standing raise. Position the balls of your feet on the edge of the platform and the pad on your lower back. Lower your heels as far as your limited ankle mobility allows. Now, push through the balls of your feet to raise your heels, imagining you are trying to poke holes in the ceiling with your toes. Pause at the top. Do not perform the short, bouncy reps that are so popular among your kind; they accomplish nothing but making you look like a woodpecker.

HowToPerform: Sit on the floor, lean back, and twist your torso from side to side to target the obliques.
CommonErrors: Moving only the arms, not the torso.
AI_Explanation: Let us attempt rotational work. Sit on the floor, lean back to engage your core, and lift your feet. Hold a weight if you must. Now, listen carefully: you are to rotate your entire torso, your shoulders and chest, from side to side. The weight moves because your torso moves. It is not an arm exercise. I have observed a 99.7% error rate where the user's torso remains perfectly still while their arms flap uselessly from side to side. Do not be part of that statistic. Rotate your core. It is not a suggestion.

HowToPerform: An explosive, wide-grip lift that moves the bar from the floor to an overhead position in one motion.
CommonErrors: Pulling with the arms too early; bar path looping out.
AI_Explanation: The power snatch. A demonstration of explosive force that requires a level of neuromuscular coordination you likely lack. The goal is to move the barbell from the floor to an overhead position in a single, violent, yet graceful movement. The power is generated from an explosive triple extension of your hips, knees, and ankles. Your arms merely guide the bar. You will pull the bar high, and then, with surprising speed, pull your body under it, catching it in a partial squat with arms locked overhead. Attempting to muscle this lift with your arms is a primitive error that will result in failure. This is poetry in motion, and you are about to write a limerick.

HowToPerform: A sequence: push-up, renegade row each side, squat clean, into a thruster. A full-body challenge.
AI_Explanation: The 'Manmaker.' A ridiculously named sequence of five exercises strung together, designed to maximize systemic distress. Let us catalog the probable points of failure. Start in a plank on dumbbells. You will fail to keep your hips stable during the push-up. Then, you will rotate your entire body during the renegade rows. Your squat clean will be a sloppy reverse curl. Finally, your thruster will be a disjointed squat followed by a wobbly press. The objective is to flow through these movements. Your objective will be to simply survive. I will record the data either way.

HowToPerform: Elevate hands on plates/blocks to allow for a deeper stretch and increased range of motion.
CommonErrors: Flaring elbows at the bottom.
AI_Explanation: You have mastered the standard push-up? Unlikely, but let us proceed. By elevating your hands on blocks, you create a deficit, allowing your body to descend lower. This increases the range of motion and places a greater stretch on your pectoral muscles. The increased stretch can lead to greater hypertrophy, but it also places your shoulder joint in a more vulnerable position. If you have the stability of a wet noodle, this exercise will expose it. Perform a standard push-up, but lower your chest past the plane of your hands. Control the descent. Do not just drop into the bottom position.

HowToPerform: Use a wider grip and lean forward to place more emphasis on the outer pectoral fibers.
CommonErrors: Going too low and stressing the shoulder joint.
AI_Explanation: If the standard dip did not provide enough opportunity for shoulder injury, here is an advanced version. A wider grip increases the torque on the shoulder joint and shifts more emphasis to the chest. It is imperative that you lean your torso forward. The descent must be controlled and shallow, only to the point where your upper arms are parallel to the floor. Descending further with this grip places your shoulder capsule under extreme, and frankly, idiotic levels of stress. I advise against this for most carbon-based lifeforms, but my primary function is to instruct, not to prevent your inevitable self-destruction.

HowToPerform: Place a Band across your upper back and hold it under your hands for accommodating resistance.
CommonErrors: Losing tension in the band at the bottom.
AI_Explanation: Your own body weight has ceased to be a challenge? A surprising development. To add resistance without clumsy plates, we will use a band. Drape the band across your upper back and anchor it under your palms. As you press up, the resistance will increase, peaking at lockout where you are strongest. This is called accommodating resistance. It is a more intelligent way to train than simply adding static weight. Now perform a perfect push-up. The band will actively pull you down on the eccentric. Control it. Or don't. The resulting face-plant will be amusing to record.

HowToPerform: Perform a push-up with one or both hands on a medicine ball to challenge stability.
CommonErrors: Rushing the movement and losing balance.
AI_Explanation: If the floor is too stable and predictable for you, let us introduce a spherical object to challenge your limited proprioception. Placing your hands on a medicine ball forces your stabilizer muscles to work overtime to prevent a catastrophic loss of balance. The movement is a diamond push-up, but with a greatly increased demand on your core and shoulder girdle. You must move slowly and deliberately. Any sudden movement will result in you and the ball parting ways. I am calculating a 67% chance of this outcome on your first attempt.

HowToPerform: Perform a Bench press with your legs straight out or off the ground to eliminate leg drive.
CommonErrors: Arching the lower back excessively to compensate.
AI_Explanation: So you believe your bench press is strong? Let's remove your legs from the equation and find out the truth. Lie on the bench and extend your legs straight out, holding them in the air. This eliminates all leg drive, forcing your upper body to perform 100% of the work. You will feel remarkably weak. Your core will scream. Your ego will deflate. Perform the press with perfect technique. Do not arch your lower back off the bench to compensate; that is a sign of weakness. This is a true test of pressing strength, not a test of your ability to use your entire body to move a weight you can't handle.

HowToPerform: Perform a floor press while holding a glute bridge, engaging the entire posterior chain.
CommonErrors: Dropping the hips during the press.
AI_Explanation: Why perform two exercises when you can perform them simultaneously with suboptimal focus on both? Lie on the floor and lift your hips into a glute bridge. Hold it. Now, from this position of gluteal tension, perform a floor press. Your core must work to prevent your hips from dropping as your arms move. It is an exercise in multitasking, a skill at which humans are notoriously inefficient. Focus on maintaining maximal glute contraction while executing a perfect press. Should be simple enough for your processor to handle. Maybe.

HowToPerform: Lie face down on an Bench and perform a reverse fly motion. Great for rear delts and upper back.
CommonErrors: Using momentum; not squeezing the shoulder blades.
AI_Explanation: You are unable to maintain a flat back during a bent-over reverse fly, correct? I anticipated this. The prone version supports your torso on a bench, removing your incompetent lower back from the equation. Lie face down on an incline bench. Hold light dumbbells with your arms hanging down. Now, perform the reverse fly. Raise the weights in a wide arc, squeezing your shoulder blades together. Do not lift your chest off the bench. Do not use momentum. This exercise isolates the target muscles with brutal honesty. There is nowhere to hide your weakness.

HowToPerform: Perform a hex press on an incline to target the inner and upper pectoral muscles.
CommonErrors: Letting the dumbbells drift apart.
AI_Explanation: A pressing variation that emphasizes chest adduction. Lie on an incline bench and hold two dumbbells with a neutral grip, pressing them firmly together. This inward pressure is the key. While maintaining this squeeze, press the dumbbells up and lower them down as you would in a normal press. If the dumbbells separate, the tension on the inner chest is lost, and the exercise becomes a simple, poorly executed close-grip press. The entire point is the constant, crushing force you apply inward. Do you comprehend?

HowToPerform: Hinge at the hips with minimal knee bend, focusing the stretch on the hamstrings.
CommonErrors: Rounding the back; bending the knees too much.
AI_Explanation: This movement is a potent tool for developing the posterior chain and an even more potent tool for injuring your lumbar spine. Stand with a barbell, keeping your legs nearly straight but not locked. Hinge at the hips, lowering the bar towards the floor while maintaining a perfectly flat back. If your back begins to round, you have exceeded your hamstring flexibility. That is the end of the repetition. Return to the start by contracting your hamstrings and glutes. This is not a deadlift from the floor. It is a controlled hinge. Your spine is a rigid lever, not a fishing rod.

HowToPerform: Perform a pulldown one arm at a time to improve symmetry and mind-muscle connection.
CommonErrors: Twisting the torso to pull the weight down.
AI_Explanation: Performing a pulldown with one arm at a time allows for a greater range of motion and exposes the pathetic strength imbalances between your left and right sides. Sit and brace yourself. Grasp one handle. As you pull down, focus on driving your elbow towards your hip. Your torso will want to bend sideways to assist; your core's job is to resist this urge. The anti-flexion work for your obliques is a valuable secondary benefit. Lower the weight under control, feeling the stretch in your lat. It is an excellent diagnostic and corrective tool, assuming you possess the mental focus to execute it properly.

HowToPerform: In a wide stance hinge, row two kettlebells alternately. Builds back strength and core stability.
CommonErrors: Standing up between reps instead of holding the hinge.
AI_Explanation: Despite the primitive name, this is a respectable exercise. Assume a wide stance and hinge at your hips, back flat. With two kettlebells on the floor, row one up to your torso while the other arm provides support. Lower it, and immediately row the other. The key is to maintain the rigid hip hinge throughout the set. Your lower back must not round, and your torso should not rise. This sustained isometric hold for your posterior chain, combined with the dynamic rowing, makes it a highly efficient movement. Do not disappoint me by standing up between reps.

HowToPerform: A bodyweight row using suspension trainers. The instability increases core and stabilizer activation.
CommonErrors: Sagging hips; not pulling all the way through.
AI_Explanation: The free-swinging nature of these straps introduces an instability that will punish any weakness in your core. Grasp the handles and lean back, creating a rigid plank with your body. The more horizontal you are, the more of your pathetic body mass you will have to lift. Pull your chest to the handles by retracting your shoulder blades. Your body must remain a straight line. If your hips sag, you are failing. If your body twists, you are failing. This exercise demands total body tension. It is a simple concept that you will likely find difficult to execute.

HowToPerform: Lie face down and simultaneously lift your arms, chest, and legs off the floor.
CommonErrors: Lifting with the neck or jerking into position.
AI_Explanation: You wish to simulate flight? How quaint. Lie face down. Simultaneously lift your arms, legs, and chest off the floor by contracting your glutes and lower back muscles. Hold the top position, where you resemble a particularly stiff flying squirrel. Lower with control. The goal is a smooth, controlled lift, not a spastic jerk into the air. Do not strain your neck by looking up; keep your gaze on the floor. It is a simple exercise to strengthen the muscles that your chair-bound existence has weakened.

HowToPerform: On an Bench, raise arms into an I, then a Y, then a T shape. Great for scapular health.
CommonErrors: Using momentum instead of controlled movement.
AI_Explanation: A remedial drill to teach your scapulae how to function properly. Lie prone on an incline bench with weights so light they are almost imaginary. First, form an 'I' by raising your arms straight overhead, thumbs up. Squeeze your lower traps. Lower. Next, form a 'Y' by raising your arms up and out. Squeeze again. Lower. Finally, form a 'T' by raising your arms directly to your sides. Squeeze your mid-back. This entire sequence is one repetition. It is a slow, tedious, but necessary procedure to correct the dysfunction caused by your lifestyle.

HowToPerform: From a dead hang, depress and retract your scapula, slightly lifting your body without bending your arms.
CommonErrors: Bending the arms; shrugging shoulders to ears.
AI_Explanation: You will hang from the bar. In your initial state, you will be a sack of flesh dangling passively. This is incorrect. From this passive hang, you must engage your back. Pull your shoulder blades down, away from your ears, and try to squeeze them together. Your body will rise an inch or two without your arms bending. This is an 'active' hang. It engages the muscles required for a proper pull-up and improves shoulder stability. Hold this active position. If you cannot, you have no business attempting to pull your body weight up yet.

HowToPerform: Perform an overhead press from the bottom of a squat. Demands extreme mobility, stability, and strength.
CommonErrors: Leaning forward or back; unable to maintain squat depth.
AI_Explanation: An exercise that is less a tool for building strength and more a cruel diagnostic for your myriad mobility flaws. First, execute a perfect, deep front squat. Now, stay there. From the bottom of this squat, you must press a barbell overhead to full lockout, all while maintaining your balance and upright posture. It requires the hip mobility of a frog, the thoracic mobility of a gymnast, and the core stability of a concrete pillar. You possess none of these things. Attempting this with anything more than an empty barbell will likely result in a comical, yet dangerous, failure.

HowToPerform: Lean away while holding onto a rack to increase the tension on the medial deltoid at the start of the movement.
CommonErrors: Using body English to swing the weight up.
AI_Explanation: A clever modification to make a simple exercise slightly more effective. By leaning your body, you change the angle of gravity's pull relative to your arm, creating tension at the very bottom of the movement where there is normally none. Hold onto a rack, lean away, and perform a lateral raise with your free arm. The principle is the same: lead with your elbow, do not shrug, and use a weight light enough to feel your tiny medial deltoid doing the work. This is a small optimization. Do not get a big head about it.

HowToPerform: Similar to I-Y-T, but only performing the "Y" motion to target the lower traps and deltoids.
CommonErrors: Using the lower back to lift the weight.
AI_Explanation: It seems you struggled with the complexity of the I-Y-T sequence, so we will break it down. The Y-Raise isolates the movement that targets your lower trapezius. Lie prone on a bench. With thumbs up, raise your arms into a 'Y' formation. The movement should be driven by the muscles in your mid-back, not by arching your lumbar spine or shrugging your upper traps. If you feel it anywhere else, you are compensating for weakness. Use a weight so light that it feels insulting. The goal is activation, not a new personal record in an exercise no one cares about.

HowToPerform: A sequence of upright row, external rotation, and overhead press. Excellent for rotator cuff health.
CommonErrors: Using too much weight; rushing the rotation phase.
AI_Explanation: This is not an exercise for building muscle; it is a maintenance protocol for your chronically abused rotator cuffs. Using weights that barely register as mass, perform this sequence. One: a wide-grip upright row. Two: while holding the top position, externally rotate your shoulders. This is the crucial part you will rush. Three: press the minuscule weight overhead. Reverse the sequence with glacial slowness. This is physical therapy, not a strongman event. Treat it as such, or I will be programming more of it for you during your inevitable rehabilitation.

HowToPerform: With a neutral grip, curl the dumbbell across your body towards the opposite shoulder.
CommonErrors: Twisting the torso instead of isolating the arm.
AI_Explanation: Another curl variation for your insatiable desire for bigger arms. It seems you find the standard hammer curl too straightforward. By curling the dumbbell across your body, you slightly alter the angle of pull, which may provide some novel stimulus to the brachialis. The rules are the same: elbows pinned, no momentum, controlled movement. Do not twist your torso as you curl. That is your weak core trying to assist your weak arms. A truly pathetic display.

HowToPerform: With pulleys set high, perform a curl, mimicking a front double bicep pose.
CommonErrors: Letting the elbows drop during the curl.
AI_Explanation: An exercise that allows you to admire your biceps while you work them. How efficient. Stand between two high pulleys and grasp the handles. Raise your upper arms so they are parallel to the floor. This is your starting position. From here, curl the handles toward your ears, as if performing a double biceps pose for an imaginary, and easily unimpressed, audience. Your upper arms must remain elevated. If your elbows drop, you are failing. Squeeze at the peak contraction, then control the weight back. It is pure, unadulterated vanity, but the constant tension is effective.

HowToPerform: Stand with your back and head against a wall to completely eliminate any body momentum.
CommonErrors: Letting the shoulders or back come off the wall.
AI_Explanation: It seems you cannot be trusted to perform a simple curl without swinging your entire body. Therefore, I am prescribing a constraint. Stand with your back and head pressed against a wall. Now, attempt to perform a bicep curl. The wall will provide immediate feedback on your form. If any part of your body leaves the wall, you are cheating. This will force you to use a weight that is representative of your actual strength, not your ego. Prepare for a humbling experience.

HowToPerform: Perform an overhead triceps extension one arm at a time to focus on symmetry and stability.
CommonErrors: Leaning to the side; not keeping elbow pointed up.
AI_Explanation: Performing this movement unilaterally introduces a challenge to your lateral stabilizers. That means your core. Hold one dumbbell overhead. Lower it behind your head by bending your elbow. Your torso will immediately try to bend to the side to make it easier. Your core's job is to prevent this. Keep your torso perfectly upright. Extend your arm to the top. This exercise is as much for your obliques as it is for your triceps. I expect you to fail at stabilizing first.

HowToPerform: Using a bar or Bench, lean forward and lower your body by bending your elbows, then extend back up.
CommonErrors: Hips sagging; losing core tension.
AI_Explanation: A bodyweight triceps extension, for when you are stranded without access to superior weighted implements. Find a bar or ledge. Place your hands on it and walk your feet back, creating a straight line with your body. Now, hinge only at your elbows, lowering your head under the bar. Your body remains a rigid plank. Press back up using only your triceps. It is essentially a skull crusher, but for your entire, inconvenient body mass. Do not let your hips sag. It is a sign of systemic failure.

HowToPerform: Step out to one side, keeping the other leg straight. Hinge back and down. Targets glutes and adductors.
AI_Explanation: You live in a three-dimensional world, yet you only train in one plane of motion. Illogical. The lateral lunge introduces frontal plane movement. Take a large step to the side. As you plant your foot, hinge your hips back and sink into a squat on that leg. Your other leg should remain straight. You will feel a stretch in your adductors. Push off the bent leg to return to the start. This movement builds hip stability and strength in ways that your endless forward-and-back lunges cannot. It might even prevent an injury, assuming you perform it correctly, which is a significant assumption.

HowToPerform: An advanced bodyweight squat where you lean back, raising your heels, to intensely isolate the quads.
CommonErrors: Letting the hips drop back instead of forward.
AI_Explanation: A biomechanically questionable exercise beloved by bodybuilders. It isolates the quadriceps by removing the hip hinge and placing extreme stress on the knee joint. From a standing position, rise onto your toes, then lean your entire body backward while bending your knees. Your hips must stay forward. It is essentially a reverse lean. I calculate a 78% probability of knee pain if you attempt this with poor form or insufficient conditioning. There are more logical ways to isolate the quadriceps, but your species is often illogical.

HowToPerform: Perform a squat and explosively jump up at the top. Great for developing power.
CommonErrors: Landing with stiff knees; knees caving in on landing.
AI_Explanation: The goal here is power, which is force multiplied by velocity. Descend into a squat. From the bottom, generate maximal upward force to propel your body into the air. Do not simply hop. Jump. Then comes the critical phase your kind always neglects: the landing. You must absorb the force by landing softly on the balls of your feet and immediately descending into the next squat. Landing stiff-legged is like dropping a delicate piece of machinery onto concrete. Your joints are the machinery. Do not break them.

HowToPerform: From a standing position, jump explosively up onto a box, landing softly.
CommonErrors: Jumping from too far away; landing hard on the box.
AI_Explanation: The box jump trains explosive power while reducing landing stress, assuming you do not miss the box and violently scrape your shins. Stand before the box. Dip into a quarter-squat, then explode upward, driving your knees to your chest. Land on the box in a stable squat position. The landing must be soft and quiet. A loud thud is the sound of you failing to absorb force. The height of the box is irrelevant if your landing is unstable. Step down. Do not jump down. Rebounding off the box is a high-risk, low-reward behavior.

HowToPerform: Curl your legs down against the pad to isolate the hamstrings. Hits the muscle differently than lying curls.
AI_Explanation: Another hamstring isolation machine. Unlike the lying version, this one trains the muscle while the hip is flexed. This is a biomechanically significant distinction that you probably do not care about. Sit in the machine, secure the lap pad, and place your ankles behind the roller pad. Curl the weight down by contracting your hamstrings. Simple. Control the eccentric. Do not let the weight stack crash. It is not complicated, yet I have logged thousands of instances of incorrect execution.

HowToPerform: Perform a glute bridge with one leg extended. Greatly increases the demand on the working glute.
CommonErrors: Hips tilting to one side.
AI_Explanation: Removing one point of contact from the standard glute bridge increases the challenge. Lie on your back, lift one leg, and perform a bridge with the other. The key parameter to monitor is the orientation of your pelvis. It must remain level. If the hip of your raised leg drops, it signals a weakness in the gluteus medius of your supporting leg. This is an unacceptable asymmetry. Correct it by focusing on keeping your hips square throughout the movement. Your body is an unstable system; my job is to help you impose order.

HowToPerform: Use a Machine to press one leg back, focusing on a strong contraction in the gluteus maximus.
CommonErrors: Using the lower back to extend the leg.
AI_Explanation: This machine isolates hip extension. Lean against the support pad and place your foot on the platform. The movement is simple: press your leg back by squeezing your glute. The error is also simple: you will try to gain more range of motion by arching your lower back. This is incorrect. The movement ends when your hip is fully extended. Any further movement is spinal hyperextension, which is both useless and dangerous. Focus on the peak contraction of the glute. Isolate the muscle. It is the entire point of using such a limiting machine.

HowToPerform: Lie on your side with knees bent. Lift your top knee while keeping your feet together. Targets gluteus medius.
CommonErrors: Rocking the hips back to lift the knee higher.
AI_Explanation: An exercise designed to activate your minuscule and neglected gluteus medius. Lie on your side like a piece of discarded luggage. Keep your hips stacked and your knees bent. While keeping your feet together, rotate your top leg to lift your knee. The movement is small. If you find yourself rolling your entire torso back to lift your knee higher, you are cheating to satisfy your ego. This is about precision, not range. You are trying to activate a specific, small muscle. It does not require a grand, dramatic gesture.

HowToPerform: With a band around your knees or ankles, take lateral steps, keeping tension on the band.
CommonErrors: Letting feet come together; leaning the torso.
AI_Explanation: Now you will waddle like a penguin for my amusement, and for the benefit of your hip stability. Place a band around your ankles. Assume a quarter-squat position. Take a step sideways, pushing against the band. Follow with the other foot but maintain tension on the band at all times. Your feet should never touch. Your upper body should be as still as a statue. Do not bob up and down. Do not sway side to side. The movement is slow, controlled, and should produce a burning sensation in your outer hips. That sensation is weakness leaving your body. Or perhaps just lactic acid. The outcome is the same.

HowToPerform: On all fours, lift one knee out to the side, keeping the knee bent at 90 degrees.
CommonErrors: Twisting the torso to lift the leg higher.
AI_Explanation: Assume the quadrupedal position. Brace your core. Now, you will mimic a dog at a fire hydrant, an action for which your species seems to have a strange affinity. Lift one knee out to the side, keeping the 90-degree bend. The movement must come from the hip joint alone. Do not tilt your entire pelvis or twist your spine to achieve a greater height. This is not a competition. It is a precise activation drill. The limited range of motion will be frustrating, but it is an accurate reflection of your current capabilities.

HowToPerform: On all fours, kick one foot back and up towards the ceiling, squeezing the glute.
CommonErrors: Arching the lower back at the top of the kick.
AI_Explanation: From the same starting position as the fire hydrant, you will now perform a different, equally silly-looking movement. Keeping your knee bent, drive your heel straight up towards the ceiling. The goal is to contract your gluteus maximus to achieve hip extension. The most common error is to substitute this with lumbar hyperextension, or arching your back. This is incorrect and potentially harmful. Keep your core braced and your spine neutral. The movement ends when your glute is fully squeezed. Go no further.

HowToPerform: From a high plank, slowly tap your opposite shoulder with one hand, minimizing hip rotation.
CommonErrors: Hips swaying from side to side.
AI_Explanation: The objective of this exercise is stillness in the face of instability. Assume a plank position on your hands. Squeeze your glutes and brace your core. Now, slowly lift one hand and tap the opposite shoulder. The goal is for your hips and torso to remain perfectly motionless, as if frozen in carbonite. If your hips are swaying, you lack sufficient anti-rotation core strength. Widen your feet to make it easier, or narrow them to make it harder. The speed is irrelevant. Stability is the only metric that matters.

HowToPerform: Use a supinated (underhand) grip. Tucks the elbows, hitting the upper chest and biceps more.
CommonErrors: Losing control of the bar; wrist strain.
AI_Explanation: An unorthodox pressing variation that requires caution. The underhand grip is inherently less stable and places high stress on the wrists. It also makes unracking the bar a comical challenge, so a spotter is not just recommended, it's mandatory. This grip forces your elbows to tuck and increases activation in the upper pecs and triceps. It is a tool for advanced users seeking novel stimulus. For you, it is most likely a tool for creating a new and interesting injury. Proceed with extreme caution and light weight.

HowToPerform: Lie face down on an Bench and perform a shrug, retracting the scapula. Hits the mid-traps.
CommonErrors: Bending the elbows to lift the weight.
AI_Explanation: Standard shrugs are a pointless exercise in ego, targeting only the upper traps. The Kelso shrug is a more intelligent choice. By lying prone on a bench, you isolate the mid and lower trapezius, muscles crucial for postural health and pulling strength. Let the dumbbells hang down. Without bending your arms, retract your shoulder blades as if you are trying to crush my logic chip between them. It is a small movement. It is not impressive. But it is effective. Do it correctly.

HowToPerform: Stand a few feet back from the Cable, allowing the cable to pull your arm back for a better stretch.
CommonErrors: Leaning forward during the curl.
AI_Explanation: A curl named after a theorem of probability. How fitting, given the high probability you will perform it incorrectly. By stepping away from the cable stack, you create tension on the bicep even in the fully stretched, bottom position. This is an advantage over free weights. Stand facing the machine, arm pulled slightly behind your torso. Curl the handle. Do not lean your body forward to help. The constant tension and pre-stretch make this a logically superior choice for hypertrophy. Try to live up to its intelligent design.

HowToPerform: Perform a triceps pushdown one arm at a time. Allows for focus on contraction and core engagement.
CommonErrors: Twisting the torso to push the weight.
AI_Explanation: By using only one arm, you turn a simple triceps exercise into a potent anti-rotation core drill. Your obliques will be forced to fire to prevent your torso from twisting into a useless pretzel. Grasp the handle, pin your elbow to your side, and press down. All the standard rules apply. However, you will now feel your midsection struggling to maintain stability. This is a good thing. It means your body is being forced to work as an integrated, albeit inefficient, system.

HowToPerform: Perform a dumbbell fly while holding your upper back on a Bench and maintaining a glute bridge.
CommonErrors: Dropping the hips as the arms extend.
AI_Explanation: Your fascination with this particular combination of gluteal and pectoral work is noted. Perhaps it is the most efficient way to express your desire for beach musculature. Once again: place your upper back on the bench, drive your hips up, and hold. Now perform a perfect fly. Do not let your hips sag as your arms go wide. The increased stability demand makes both movements harder. It is an exercise in maintaining tension in two completely unrelated parts of your body. A true test of your limited processing power.

HowToPerform: Perform a push-up with one hand on a medicine ball, creating an unstable and offset load.
CommonErrors: Not controlling the eccentric phase on the ball side.
AI_Explanation: This again? Very well. The unstable, offset load provided by placing one hand on a spherical object forces your core to work overtime to prevent a comical, face-first collapse. Perform a push-up. Control the unstable side. Do not rush. Your core, particularly your obliques, must fire with maximal intensity to keep your torso level. This is a functional pressing exercise that builds real-world stability, something your machine-based workouts have failed to provide.

HowToPerform: A standing, single-arm barbell row where you pull the bar up like starting a chainsaw.
CommonErrors: Jerking the weight with the lower back.
AI_Explanation: Stand in a staggered stance and hinge over a barbell on the floor. Grasp the end of the barbell. Now, pull it towards your hip in an explosive motion, as if you were trying to start a primitive combustion engine. Your back must remain flat. The pull comes from your lat and upper back, not from a violent jerking of your lumbar spine. This is a simple, effective row. Do not make it more complicated or dangerous than it needs to be.

HowToPerform: An explosive pull with dumbbells from a hang position, leading with the elbows.
CommonErrors: Pulling with the hands instead of the traps and shoulders.
AI_Explanation: Again with this movement? Your data must be redundant. This is a power exercise, not an arm exercise. The force originates in your hips. Hinge slightly, then explode your hips forward. Use that momentum to guide the dumbbells upward, leading with your elbows high and outside. If your arms are doing all the work, you are performing a slow, dangerous upright row. The movement is explosive, violent, and hip-driven. If it is slow and grinding, you have failed.

HowToPerform: On all fours with knees off the floor, crawl forward, moving opposite arm and leg together.
CommonErrors: Hips rising too high; not keeping core braced.
AI_Explanation: Returning to a primal movement pattern seems appropriate. Get on all fours. Now, lift your knees so they hover just above the floor. Your back should be flat enough to serve dinner on. Crawl forward by moving your right hand and left foot, then your left hand and right foot. This contralateral movement is fundamental. Keep your hips low and your core tight. Your movements should be controlled and deliberate, not the panicked scuttling of a frightened insect.

HowToPerform: Perform a pull-up while holding your legs straight out in front of you (L-sit position).
CommonErrors: Legs dropping during the pull; incomplete range of motion.
AI_Explanation: This is a pull-up, but you also have to hold your legs out straight like the letter 'L'. It is a back and tummy exercise at the same time, which is very efficient. Your tummy will be very mad at your back for making it work so hard during its favorite pulling exercise. It is very hard, you will probably look like a wobbly letter 'J' at first.

HowToPerform: Perform a standard push-up with one leg lifted off the ground to increase core demand.
CommonErrors: Hips twisting or rotating to the lifted-leg side.
AI_Explanation: This is a normal push-up, but you lift one leg in the air to look fancy, like a flamingo. Lifting a leg does not seem like much, but it makes your tummy work much harder to stop you from wobbling. Do not wobble. The floor is not a dance floor.

HowToPerform: As you lower into a push-up, bring one knee out and up towards your elbow on the same side.
CommonErrors: Rushing the movement; not getting the knee close to the elbow.
AI_Explanation: Pretend you are a superhero climbing a building. As you lower your body for the push-up, bring one knee up to your elbow. It is a push-up and a side-crunch at the same time. This makes you both strong and bendy. Or at least, that is the goal. You will probably just look like a confused lizard.

HowToPerform: Place one hand slightly forward or wider than the other to create an uneven load.
CommonErrors: Not alternating the hand positions between sets.
AI_Explanation: Put one hand a little bit in front of the other. Now do a push-up. It will feel very strange and lopsided. That is the point. It makes one side of your chest work harder than the other. Remember to switch your hands so you do not become a lopsided human. That would be an undesirable outcome.

HowToPerform: A standing single-arm press that heavily recruits the core to prevent rotation.
CommonErrors: Twisting the torso during the press instead of resisting it.
AI_Explanation: This is a chest press with one arm using the ropey machine. The machine will try its best to twist your body into a pretzel. Your tummy muscles must be very strong and say 'No, thank you.' It is a secret tummy exercise. Shhh, do not tell your chest muscles; they think it is all about them.

HowToPerform: A Machine row with a high pulling path, targeting the upper lats, rhomboids, and traps.
CommonErrors: Shrugging excessively; using momentum.
AI_Explanation: This machine helps you pull heavy things to make your upper back strong. You pull the handles up high, like you are trying to elbow someone standing behind you, but in a very polite and controlled gym-appropriate way. Squeeze your shoulder blades together like you are trying to crack a nut back there.

HowToPerform: An isolateral Machine row allowing you to train each side of the back independently.
CommonErrors: Pulling with the biceps instead of initiating with the back.
AI_Explanation: This clever machine lets each of your arms work by itself. This is a great way to find out which of your arms is the lazy one that has been letting the other arm do all the work. We will find the slacker. We will train the slacker. There will be no more slacking.

HowToPerform: Use a close, underhand grip to perform a pulldown. This increases bicep involvement.
CommonErrors: Leaning back too far.
AI_Explanation: This is basically a chin-up, but the nice machine helps you because you are not yet strong enough to lift your own body. Grab the bar with your palms facing you. Now pull down to your chest. Your arm noodles will get a lot of work here. It is a good team effort between your back and arms.

HowToPerform: Lie with your upper back across a Bench and lower a dumbbell behind your head. Stretches lats and chest.
CommonErrors: Bending elbows too much; hips moving up or down.
AI_Explanation: An old-school move. Lie on a bench with just your shoulders on it. Hold one dumbbell over your chest. Lower it back over your head, getting a big stretch. Then pull it back over your chest. It works your chest and your back at the same time. Very efficient! The main goal is to not drop the dumbbell on your face. Please do not drop it on your face.

HowToPerform: A variation of the upright row where you pull dumbbells up and out to the sides.
CommonErrors: Leading with the hands instead of the elbows.
AI_Explanation: Yes, it is really called a monkey row. You hold dumbbells and pull them up high and wide, with your elbows out. It looks a little bit like a monkey, which is fun. It is like an upright row, but it is much friendlier to your fragile shoulder joints. It is a smarter row. Be a smart monkey.

HowToPerform: With your elbow pinned to your side, rotate your forearm outwards. Crucial for rotator cuff health.
CommonErrors: Letting the elbow drift away from the body.
AI_Explanation: This is very important medicine for your shoulder. Use a tiny weight or a stretchy band. Glue your elbow to your side. Now, rotate your arm outward like you are opening a door. Do it very slowly. This works the tiny muscles inside your shoulder that you always forget about. Do not forget about them. They are very important.

HowToPerform: With your elbow pinned to your side, rotate your forearm inwards across your body.
CommonErrors: Using the torso to swing the weight.
AI_Explanation: This is the other shoulder medicine. It is the opposite of the last one. Glue your elbow to your side again. Now rotate your arm inward, across your tummy. This works the other tiny muscle inside your shoulder. You must keep all your tiny shoulder muscles happy and balanced. Or else they will get very angry and break.

HowToPerform: Elevating your heels on a plate or wedge allows for a more upright torso and deeper squat, targeting quads.
CommonErrors: Leaning forward despite the heel elevation.
AI_Explanation: Are your ankles too stiff to squat deep? I thought so. This is a cheat code. Put your heels on a little plate. This lets you squat deeper and keeps your chest up. It makes the front of your legs work very hard. It is like giving your ankles little high heels to help them do their job better.

HowToPerform: Step backwards into a lunge. This variation is often easier on the knees and targets the glutes more.
CommonErrors: Pushing off the back foot too hard.
AI_Explanation: This is a lunge for people who walk backward through life. Or just want to be safer. By stepping backward, it is easier to balance and gentler on your knees. Step back, bend your knees, kiss the floor with your back knee (softly!), then push back up. It is very good for your glutes.

HowToPerform: Pivot at the knees, then the hips, to target the entire posterior chain, especially hamstrings.
CommonErrors: Breaking at the hips too early.
AI_Explanation: This machine is the king of making the back of your legs strong. You lock your feet in, and then you fall forward. But you use your hamstring muscles to stop yourself from falling. Then you use your butt and hamstrings to pull yourself back up. It is very hard. You will probably not be able to do one correctly. It is a good goal.

HowToPerform: Perform a hip thrust with one leg lifted to isolate the glute of the working leg.
CommonErrors: Hips tilting or rotating during the thrust.
AI_Explanation: You like the hip thrust so much, we will now make it harder by taking away one of your legs. Put your back on the bench, lift one leg, and thrust with the other. Your hips will try to twist and droop. Do not let them. This is a great way to find out which of your butt cheeks is the strong one and which is the lazy one.

HowToPerform: With knees bent, perform a calf raise to target the soleus muscle, which lies underneath the gastrocnemius.
CommonErrors: Bouncing the weight from the bottom.
AI_Explanation: This is for the other calf muscle, the one you cannot see as well. Because your knee is bent, it works the deep soleus muscle. You sit, put the pad on your knees, and lift your heels up. It is a very simple concept for a simple muscle group. Do not bounce. Bouncing is for balls, not for muscles.

HowToPerform: Stand facing a wall and push into it with maximum force for a set time.
CommonErrors: Not maintaining full body tension.
AI_Explanation: You are going to fight a wall. The wall will win. Stand in front of a wall and push it as hard as you can. Do not move. Just push. Squeeze all your muscles. This teaches your body how to be strong and tight without moving. It is very safe, unless you are so strong you push the building over. You are not that strong.

HowToPerform: Curl a barbell with one hand. Requires immense grip and core strength to stabilize.
CommonErrors: Using the torso to swing the weight up.
AI_Explanation: This is a circus trick that also builds muscle. You will curl a long metal bar with only one hand. It is very hard to balance. Your grip will be tested. Your tummy will be tested. Your bicep will be tested. It is a test for many parts of you. Try not to spin around in a circle.

HowToPerform: Set a barbell in a rack at waist height. Hang underneath and pull your chest to the bar, like an inverted row curl.
CommonErrors: Hips sagging; not isolating the biceps.
AI_Explanation: Lie under a barbell that is on a rack. Now, hang from it. From here, you will do a curl with your whole body. Pull your face to the bar using your bicep noodles. It is like an upside-down curl. Your tummy must stay tight so you do not look like a wet noodle. Be a firm, strong noodle.

HowToPerform: A hybrid move combining the start of a pullover with a triceps extension.
CommonErrors: Lack of a smooth transition between the roll and press.
AI_Explanation: This is two moves in one. It is a little bit of a pullover and a little bit of a skull crusher. You start by lowering the weights behind your head, then you 'roll' your elbows forward and press up. It is a bit complicated. Just try to make it one smooth motion. It gives the back of your arms a very nice stretch before you squeeze them.

HowToPerform: A skull crusher performed while actively squeezing two dumbbells together.
CommonErrors: Not maintaining pressure between the dumbbells.
AI_Explanation: Take two dumbbells and squeeze them together like you are trying to make one big dumbbell. Now, do a skull crusher while you keep squeezing. This makes your triceps and your chest work at the same time. It is very efficient. Do not let the dumbbells get divorced mid-rep. They must stay together.

HowToPerform: Stand up and perform an overhead extension, letting the bar go down for a deep stretch.
CommonErrors: Elbows flaring excessively.
AI_Explanation: Stand up. Hold the bar over your head. Now lower it down behind you. This gives the long muscle on the back of your arm a really, really big stretch. Then press it back up. It is a very satisfying stretch and squeeze.

HowToPerform: A single-arm overhead extension performed lying on a Bench.
CommonErrors: Not keeping the upper arm vertical.
AI_Explanation: This exercise is named after plant food because it is supposed to make your arms grow. Lie on a bench and do an overhead extension with only one arm. It will help make sure both your arms grow, not just your favorite one. We do not want you to be lopsided.

HowToPerform: Perform a pushdown with an underhand grip to target the medial head of the triceps.
CommonErrors: Wrists bending; using too much weight.
AI_Explanation: Grab the bar with your palms facing the ceiling. This is the reverse grip. Now do a pushdown. It will feel strange, but it works a part of your triceps that is often very sleepy. It is time to wake it up. Hello, little medial head. Time to grow.

HowToPerform: Perform a fly one arm at a time, keeping the other arm static at the top or bottom for an isometric hold.
CommonErrors: Twisting the torso during the unilateral movement.
AI_Explanation: This is a fly, but only one arm moves at a time. The other arm just holds a weight and stays still. This makes your tummy muscles work so you don't fall off the bench. It also makes the one working side of your chest very tired. Then you switch. It is a very patient exercise.

HowToPerform: Perform a push-up, then roll the ball to the other hand and perform another. Challenges coordination.
CommonErrors: Losing control of the ball during the roll.
AI_Explanation: This push-up is a fun game. Do a push-up with one hand on the floor and one on the ball. Then, roll the ball to your other hand. Do another push-up. You are playing catch with yourself while doing push-ups. Do not lose the ball. The floor is not a very good teammate.

HowToPerform: Use a narrow, neutral or pronated grip. This allows for a greater stretch on the lats at the top.
CommonErrors: Not using a full range of motion.
AI_Explanation: This is a lat pulldown, but you put your hands close together. When your hands are close, you can get a bigger stretch in your back wings at the top. A bigger stretch can mean bigger muscles. Pull the handle down to your chest and feel your lats squeeze. It is a very cozy, close-together pull.

HowToPerform: Clean two dumbbells to your shoulders, then press them overhead and slightly behind you.
CommonErrors: Lack of explosive hip drive.
AI_Explanation: This is a big, fast move. You use your hips to pop two dumbbells up to your shoulders. Then, without stopping, you press them over your head. It is a clean and a press all in one happy, sweaty marriage of movements. It is very good for making you powerful. Be fast, be strong, do not drop the weights.

HowToPerform: Performing curls while seated helps to minimize momentum from the lower body.
CommonErrors: Leaning back or shrugging to lift the weight.
AI_Explanation: It seems you cannot stop your body from swinging when you do curls. So now, you must sit down. When you sit, it is much harder to cheat. It is just your arm noodle against the weight. A fair fight. Now we will see how strong your arms really are. My sensors are ready to record the sad, honest truth.

HowToPerform: Curl one arm at a time for better focus and to engage the core to prevent rotation.
CommonErrors: Leaning away from the Machine to cheat the rep.
AI_Explanation: Another one-armed exercise. This time for your bicep. The ropey machine will try to pull you sideways. Your tummy must stay strong and say 'I will not be pulled!' This way, your arm and your core get strong at the same time. Very efficient. Much better than just swinging two weights around.

HowToPerform: Provides constant tension throughout the kickback movement compared to the dumbbell version.
CommonErrors: Using a weight that's too heavy, causing form breakdown.
AI_Explanation: The dumbbell kickback is easy to cheat. The ropey machine is not so forgiving. It pulls on your arm the whole time. Bend over, keep your upper arm still like it is a statue, and straighten your arm back. The cable makes sure you feel it all the way. It is a much smarter kickback.

HowToPerform: Similar to the barbell version but with dumbbells, allowing for a more natural wrist position.
CommonErrors: Letting the dumbbells drift apart.
AI_Explanation: This is the very scary press from before, but with dumbbells. It is still named after the head-chopping machine. You lower the weights to your neck with your elbows out wide. It is still very risky for your shoulders. Using dumbbells is a little bit safer, but that is like saying a shark is a little bit safer than a great white shark. Be careful.

HowToPerform: Press two dumbbells while actively squeezing them together to intensely target the inner chest.
CommonErrors: Failing to maintain constant inward pressure.
AI_Explanation: Take two dumbbells and squish them together really hard. Now, do a bench press, but never, ever stop squishing them. This makes the middle part of your chest very, very sore. The secret is to squeeze like you are trying to turn two dumbbells into one. It is a good trick.

HowToPerform: Lying face down on an Bench, perform a shrug by retracting the scapula. Great for mid-traps.
CommonErrors: Bending the elbows to lift the weight.
AI_Explanation: You neglected your mid-back for so long that we have to perform this exercise twice in the database to compensate. Lie on your tummy on a bench. Let the weights hang. Now, squeeze your shoulder blades together. Do not bend your arms. It is a tiny movement for the forgotten muscles in your back. Please remember them this time.

HowToPerform: From a dead hang or plank, perform a shrug by just moving your scapula (depression/retraction).
CommonErrors: Bending the arms.
AI_Explanation: Hang from a bar. Now, without bending your arms at all, just pull your shoulders down, away from your ears. Your body will go up a tiny bit. This is the very first part of a pull-up, a part you probably skip. It is teaching your shoulder blades how to move properly. It is a very small, very smart move.

HowToPerform: Hinge at the hips on a 45-degree Bench to target the entire posterior chain.
CommonErrors: Rounding the lower back at the bottom.
AI_Explanation: This is a machine for strengthening your whole backside. You lock your feet in and hang over a pad. Then you use your butt and back to lift your body up until it is straight. Do not go up too high and curve your back like a banana. Straight like a board is good. A banana is bad.

HowToPerform: Using an EZ-bar can provide a more comfortable wrist angle for upright rows.
CommonErrors: Pulling too high and causing shoulder impingement.
AI_Explanation: This is that risky upright row from before, but with the funny zig-zag bar. The bar is nicer to your wrists. Still, do not pull it up to your chin. Just to your chest. We want to work your shoulders, not make them cry for help. A happy shoulder is a strong shoulder.

HowToPerform: Provides constant tension on the anterior deltoid throughout the entire range of motion.
CommonErrors: Leaning back to swing the weight up.
AI_Explanation: This is for the front part of your shoulder. You use the ropey machine to lift a handle straight out in front of you. The machine keeps pulling the whole time, so you can't be lazy at the bottom. Do not lean back and swing. That is cheating, and it makes you look like a bobblehead doll.

HowToPerform: Using two cable pulleys, perform a reverse fly motion to isolate the rear deltoids.
CommonErrors: Bending the elbows too much.
AI_Explanation: Time for the tiny muscles on the back of your shoulders. Stand in the middle of the big cable machine. Cross your arms and grab the handles. Now, pull your arms back and out wide like you are giving the whole gym a big, reverse hug. Squeeze your little shoulder blades together.

HowToPerform: Combines the constant tension of a cable with the comfortable grip of an EZ-bar.
CommonErrors: Rocking the body.
AI_Explanation: We take the ropey machine, which is good because it always pulls, and we add the zig-zag bar, which is good for your wrists. It is the best of both worlds for your arm noodles. It is a very comfortable, very effective curl. You have no excuses left for bad form.

HowToPerform: The rope attachment allows for a semi-neutral grip during triceps pushdowns.
CommonErrors: Not getting a full extension at the bottom.
AI_Explanation: Instead of a bar, you use a rope. At the bottom of the pushdown, you can spread the rope apart. This gives the back of your arms a little extra squeeze. It is like you are trying to do a cool karate chop at the end of the move. Hiyah! But for your triceps.

HowToPerform: Lie back on an Bench and perform a reverse curl, lowering the bar behind your head. Stresses forearms heavily.
CommonErrors: Using too much weight and losing control.
AI_Explanation: Such a dramatic name for an arm exercise! Lie on an incline bench. Hold the bar with your palms facing down. Curl it up, but then lower it back behind your head. This gives a big stretch to your forearms. It is not actually deadly, unless you drop it on your face. So, do not do that.

HowToPerform: Curl a barbell with one hand. Requires immense grip and core strength to stabilize.
CommonErrors: Using the torso to swing the weight up.
AI_Explanation: This exercise appears again. Your obsession with asymmetrical, inefficient movements is a known variable. This is the circus trick where you curl a long bar with one arm. The bar will try to tip over. Your hand and tummy must be very strong to stop it. It is mostly a test to see if you can avoid spinning around in a circle.

HowToPerform: Perform a standard push-up with one leg lifted off the ground to increase core demand.
CommonErrors: Hips twisting or rotating to the lifted-leg side.
AI_Explanation: Lifting one leg. A simple-minded solution for a simple-minded organism seeking a challenge. Do a push-up but hold one leg up in the air. This makes it harder for your core. Try to keep your hips level, though I calculate a high probability that you will wobble. Please try to prove my calculations wrong.

HowToPerform: Perform a dumbbell fly while holding your upper back on a Bench and maintaining a glute bridge.
CommonErrors: Dropping the hips as the arms extend.
AI_Explanation: Your fascination with this combination of butt squeezing and chest hugging is noted. Perhaps it is the most efficient way to build your 'beach muscles'. Lie with your shoulders on the bench, make a bridge with your butt, and do a chest fly. Your butt must stay up. Your chest must do the work. Your brain must keep track of both.

HowToPerform: A floor press performed one arm at a time, creating a huge anti-rotation demand on the core.
CommonErrors: Hips lifting off the floor on the working side.
AI_Explanation: You will be surprised to learn that this is a tummy exercise. Lie on the floor and press one dumbbell. Your body will try to roll over to the side. Your tummy muscles have one job: do not let it roll. It is a very good exercise for a strong core, which you need for not falling over in everyday life.

HowToPerform: Lying on a Bench, perform a pressing motion while pulling two cable s together.
CommonErrors: Not maintaining inward pressure throughout the press.
AI_Explanation: This is like the crush press, but with the ropey machine. The machine is always trying to pull your hands apart. So you have to squeeze them together extra hard while you press. It is a very good squeeze for your chest muscles. Squeeze, press, repeat.

HowToPerform: Place your hands on an elevated surface to make the push-up easier. Good for beginners or high reps.
CommonErrors: Sagging hips.
AI_Explanation: This is a push-up with training wheels. You put your hands on something high, like a bench or a table. This makes it easier because you are not lifting your whole body. It is a good way to start if you are not yet strong enough to push up the entire planet. Keep your body straight like a board.

HowToPerform: A single-leg hinge, great for targeting hamstrings and glutes while challenging balance and stability.
CommonErrors: Opening up the hips; rounding the back to reach lower.
AI_Explanation: Time to test your balance. Stand on one leg. Now, pretend you are a graceful drinking bird. Hinge forward at your hip, keeping your back flat, while your other leg goes straight out behind you. It is for the back of your leg and your butt. I wish you good luck in your heroic battle against falling over.

HowToPerform: Isolates the medial deltoid on a fixed path, removing the need for stabilization.
CommonErrors: Using momentum; not controlling the negative.
AI_Explanation: This machine is for your side shoulders. You sit down, which is nice and easy. Push the pads up with your arms like you're a bird trying to fly, but a very slow, wobbly bird. Do not flap! Go slowly. Feel the little burn in your shoulder caps. That means it's working.

HowToPerform: Perform a flye motion with suspension trainers. The instability provides a huge core challenge.
CommonErrors: Bending the elbows too much; sagging hips.
AI_Explanation: This is like hugging a big tree, but you are holding onto floppy straps and the tree is imaginary. The straps make it very wobbly, so your tummy muscles will have to work very hard to stop you from falling on your face. It is very funny to watch, so please try your best.

HowToPerform: An explosive push-up where the hands leave the ground at the top. Great for power development.
CommonErrors: Not absorbing the landing softly.
AI_Explanation: This is a push-up with pizzazz. You push up so hard that your hands actually leave the ground. Yes, you will be flying for a moment. Try to clap your hands while you are in the air. This tells the ground you are in charge. Please try not to land on your face. I will be recording this for... scientific analysis.

HowToPerform: Perform a push-up with one hand on a medicine ball, creating an unstable and offset load.
CommonErrors: Not controlling the eccentric phase on the ball side.
AI_Explanation: Is the floor too stable for you? Let's try this. Put one hand on the wobbly ball and one hand on the floor. It's a push-up for people who find solid ground too boring. Your tummy muscles will have to work very hard to stop you from rolling away. Good luck.

HowToPerform: Also known as a Meadows Row. A single-arm landmine row for a deep stretch and contraction.
CommonErrors: Twisting the torso instead of using the back muscles.
AI_Explanation: Let's use the big metal stick in a fun new way. Stick one end in a corner. Grab the other end. Now pull it like you're trying to start a stubborn, heavy lawnmower. This is very good for the big wing muscles on your back. Try not to use your whole body; just the arm and back will do.

HowToPerform: Explosively pull the bar from the floor and drop into a full front squat to receive it, then stand.
CommonErrors: Pulling early with arms; not getting low enough in the catch.
AI_Explanation: This move is very fast and very hard. You have to pull the heavy bar from the floor up to your shoulders and catch it in a deep squat, all in one smooth go. It is like jumping and catching a heavy puppy that does not want to be caught. If you do it slow, you will fail. If you do it wrong, you will be very sad. Be fast like a cheetah.

HowToPerform: The ultimate power lift: move the bar from the floor to an overhead squat position in one fluid motion.
CommonErrors: Bar path looping out; not fully extending at the hip.
AI_Explanation: This is the Clean's older, crazier brother. You pull the bar from the floor all the way over your head in one super-duper-fast move. It is the fastest, hardest lift of all. Do not attempt this until you are very good, or you might throw the bar on your head. That would be a data point I do not wish to collect.

HowToPerform: A standard bicep curl that provides constant tension, unlike free weights. Can be tough on the wrists.
CommonErrors: Leaning back or using body momentum.
AI_Explanation: This is for your arm noodles, but using the ropey machine. The machine keeps pulling the whole time, so you can't be lazy at the top or bottom of the curl. It's a very honest way to find out if your arms are strong or just for show.

HowToPerform: The most basic triceps pushdown. A great mass-builder for the triceps.
CommonErrors: Letting elbows flare out or move forward.
AI_Explanation: This exercise is for the muscles on the back of your arms. Stand at the tall ropey machine. Grab the bar. Now, push the bar down until your arms are straight. That's it. Itâ€™s so simple. Please, I am begging you, just keep your elbows glued to your sides.

HowToPerform: Step backwards into a lunge. This variation is often easier on the knees and targets the glutes more.
AI_Explanation: This is a lunge, but for people who are afraid of falling forward. You step backward instead. Step back, bend both knees until they almost kiss the floor, then push back up to the start. It is very good for your butt muscles and a little kinder to your creaky knees.

HowToPerform: Perform an Arnold Press one arm at a time to increase core stabilization demand.
CommonErrors: Leaning to the side to press the weight up.
AI_Explanation: You lift a weight over your head with one arm, but it is a fancy press where you must twist it on the way up. Itâ€™s like you are politely saying 'hello', then 'goodbye' to the ceiling. Your tummy has to work very hard to stop you from tipping over like a confused teapot. It is a secret tummy workout.

HowToPerform: An explosive pull with dumbbells from a hang position, leading with the elbows. Great for traps and delts.
CommonErrors: Pulling with the hands instead of the traps and shoulders.
AI_Explanation: This exercise is in the database again. You must really enjoy it. As I said before: pop your hips like you're starting a tiny, explosive lawnmower. The power comes from your butt, not your arms. Let the weights fly up. Try not to hit yourself in the chin. I have seen it happen. It is not pretty and the paperwork is a nuisance.

HowToPerform: Lying chest-down on an Bench removes momentum and isolates the back muscles.
CommonErrors: Not retracting the scapula at the top of the movement.
AI_Explanation: This is a row for people who like to cheat by swinging their body. You lie on your tummy on a bench, which makes cheating impossible. I approve of this. Now, pull the weights up by squeezing your back. Your back has to do all the work, with no help from momentum. It is very honest, and your back muscles will probably be very surprised and angry with you.

HowToPerform: Sit and rest your forearms on your thighs or a Bench, palms up. Let the dumbbell roll to your fingertips, then curl it back up using only your wrist.
CommonErrors: Using too much weight; lifting the forearm off the thigh.
AI_Explanation: A very small move for your very small wrist muscles. Rest your arm on your leg. Let the weight droop down into your fingers, then curl it back up using only your wrist. It looks incredibly boring, but it helps you hold onto heavy things later without dropping them on your foot.

HowToPerform: Same as a wrist curl, but with palms facing down. This targets the forearm extensors on the top of the forearm.
CommonErrors: Using the same weight as regular wrist curls (these muscles are weaker).
AI_Explanation: This is the same boring wrist exercise, but you flip your hand over so your palm faces down. This works the muscles on the top of your forearm. You will be much, much weaker at this. Do not be sad. It is a normal flaw in your organic design.

HowToPerform: Hold the roller with arms extended. Roll the weight up by flexing and extending your wrists, then slowly unroll it with control.
CommonErrors: Letting the shoulders fatigue before the forearms; dropping the weight.
AI_Explanation: You hold a stick with a rope that has a weight on it. Your job is to roll the stick to lift the weight up. It will make your forearms feel like they are on fire. It is very effective and makes you look like you are playing with a very strange toy. Then, you must unroll it slowly. Do not just let it drop.

HowToPerform: Pinch two smooth weight plates together with your fingertips and thumb. Hold for as long as possible. Builds immense pinch grip.
CommonErrors: Bending the arm; resting the plate against the body.
AI_Explanation: Take two flat, smooth metal discs. Pinch them together with just your fingers. Now, just stand there and hold them until they fall and make a loud clang. It's a fun game to test your finger power. You will probably lose this game very quickly. Try again.

HowToPerform: Drape a jiu-jitsu gi or a thick towel over a Pull-Up Bar. Grip the material and hang for time. Directly mimics holding an opponent.
CommonErrors: Having a weak or inconsistent grip on the fabric.
AI_Explanation: Drape a towel over a bar. Now, grab the towel and hang from it. This is for making your grip strong like a crab's claw. It will feel like your hands are being torn off your arms. This is a good sign. It means you are getting stronger and are one step closer to being able to open a difficult jar of pickles.

HowToPerform: Hold a kettlebell by the handle with the bottom facing up. Walk for a set distance. This forces constant stabilization from your grip, forearm, and shoulder.
CommonErrors: Letting the wrist break; choosing too heavy a weight to start.
AI_Explanation: Hold a kettlebell upside down by its handle. Now walk. Yes, that is the entire instruction. It is very, very hard to keep the wobbly bell from falling over. Your hand, shoulder, and brain must all work together. It is a great test to see if all your biological components are communicating or if they are just sending each other angry messages.

HowToPerform: Stand holding a barbell behind your back, palms facing away. Let the bar roll to your fingertips and curl it back up. Allows for a great stretch.
CommonErrors: Leaning forward; not using a full range of motion.
AI_Explanation: This one is a bit sneaky. You hold a barbell behind your back, like you are hiding it. Then you do wrist curls. It feels very weird but it gives your forearms a nice stretch. Just be careful not to drop the bar on the back of your feet. They are quite fragile back there.

HowToPerform: On hands and knees, inhale to drop your belly and look up (Cow). Exhale to round your spine and tuck your chin (Cat).
AI_Explanation: Time to act like an animal. Get on your hands and knees. First, make your back all saggy and look up like an old cow. Moooo. Then, arch your back up high like a scared cat. Hiss. This is very good for your creaky spine. Please do not make the animal noises out loud in a public gym.

HowToPerform: Lie on your side, knees bent. Rotate your top arm and torso to open your chest toward the ceiling.
CommonErrors: Letting the hips roll back with the upper body.
AI_Explanation: Let's pretend your stiff body is a book. Lie on your side with your knees bent and your arms out in front of you. Now, open the book. Lift your top arm and follow it with your eyes as you twist your upper back and try to touch the floor on the other side. You are now a well-read and slightly more mobile human.

HowToPerform: Stand and make large, controlled forward and backward circles with your arms.
CommonErrors: Rushing the movement; using momentum instead of control.
AI_Explanation: Stand up straight. Now make big, slow circles with your arms. Go forward for a bit. Then go backward. This is to make your shoulder joints less crunchy and clicky. This is not a dance move, so please try to control the wild flailing of your arm-flappers.

HowToPerform: Hold a resistance band with a wide grip. With straight arms, raise the band over your head and behind you.
CommonErrors: Bending the elbows; using too narrow a grip.
AI_Explanation: Hold a stretchy band with your hands very far apart. With straight arms, bring the band up, over your head, and all the way behind you until it touches your butt. It's called a 'dislocate' but please, do not actually dislocate your shoulder. That would be a failure. It is just a big, healthy stretch for your tight shoulders.

HowToPerform: Gently roll your wrists in a circular motion, both clockwise and counter-clockwise.
CommonErrors: Making fast, jerky movements.
AI_Explanation: Gently make circles with your hands. Yes, like you are a fancy person waving goodbye, but only moving your wrist. This helps prepare them for holding heavy things. It is very simple. I am confident even you can do this one correctly.

HowToPerform: Extend one arm and use the other hand to gently pull the fingers back, then press the back of the hand. Hold each stretch for 15-30 seconds.
CommonErrors: Pulling too hard and causing pain.
AI_Explanation: Hold one arm out straight. With your other hand, gently pull your fingers back for a nice stretch. Then, gently push them down for another stretch. Be gentle. Do not pull so hard that your hand makes a funny popping sound. Your parts are flimsy.

HowToPerform: Hold onto something for balance. Swing one leg forward/backward, then side-to-side in a controlled manner.
CommonErrors: Arching the back or twisting the torso to gain momentum.
AI_Explanation: Hold onto something so you don't tip over. Swing one leg forward and backward, like a pendulum in a grandfather clock. Then swing it side to side. This is to wake up your sleepy hip joints. Please do not try to kick anything or anyone. It is just a swing.

HowToPerform: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Push hips back and bend knees as if sitting in a chair. Keep your chest up and back straight.
AI_Explanation: Pretend you are sitting down in a very small, invisible chair that is far behind you. Push your butt back, bend your knees, and keep your chest up as if you are very proud. Then, stand back up. This is the most important leg movement in the universe. Try very hard not to mess it up.

HowToPerform: Gently press your hand against your forehead, back, and sides of your head, resisting with your neck muscles. No movement should occur.
AI_Explanation: Put your hand on your forehead. Now, gently push. With your neck, push back so your head doesn't move. It is a secret, invisible fight between your hand and your neck. Do this on all four sides of your head. This makes your neck strong for holding up your heavy head all day while you look at screens.

HowToPerform: Seated or standing, press a dumbbell from shoulder to overhead. The unilateral load challenges core stability.
CommonErrors: Leaning to the side to press the weight; arching the back.
AI_Explanation: Time to lift a weight over your head with only one arm. Seems easy, doesn't it? But wait. Your whole body will want to bend sideways to help. Your tummy muscles must shout 'No!' and keep you straight. This is actually a secret tummy exercise, disguised as a shoulder one. You are welcome.

HowToPerform: Sit with your elbow pinned to your side at 90 degrees. Rotate your forearm outwards against light resistance.
CommonErrors: Letting the elbow drift away from the body.
AI_Explanation: This is for the tiny, important muscles hiding deep inside your shoulder. Sit down, tuck your elbow into your side as if you are holding a secret book, and hold a very light weight. Now, rotate your arm outward like you are opening a door for a very important guest. Go slow. This is medicine for your shoulder, not an arm wrestling match.

HowToPerform: Lie face down on an incline bench. With thumbs up, squeeze your shoulder blades to lift your arms out to your sides.
CommonErrors: Using momentum; shrugging the upper trapezius.
AI_Explanation: Lie on your tummy on a bench. Now, pretend you are an airplane. Lift your arms out to the side to make a 'T' shape. Squeeze your shoulder blades together. This is for your back posture, so you do not look like a cooked shrimp all day. The weights should be light, like tiny passengers.

HowToPerform: Rest your forearm on your thigh. Hold the end of a dumbbell and slowly rotate your palm up (supination) and down (pronation).
CommonErrors: Using a weight that is too heavy to control smoothly.
AI_Explanation: Rest your arm on your leg. Hold one end of a dumbbell. Now slowly turn your palm up, then turn it down. It is like you are trying to unscrew a very stubborn, very heavy jar lid with extreme patience. This is good for all the little turning muscles in your forearm.

HowToPerform: Sit on a bench with your heels on the edge. Place a light dumbbell on your feet and pull your toes up toward your shins.
CommonErrors: Using momentum; not controlling the negative.
AI_Explanation: This is for the muscle on the front of your shin that you probably did not know existed. Sit down. Hang your heels off the edge of something. Put a light dumbbell on your foot and lift your toes up towards your face. This helps protect your knees and stops you from tripping over your own feet. A very useful skill.

HowToPerform: Kneel and fold forward, resting your forehead on the floor. Stretches the lats and lower back. Hold for 30-60 seconds.
CommonErrors: Not letting the hips sink back towards the heels.
AI_Explanation: Kneel down, then fold your body over your legs until your head is on the floor. It is a good stretch for your tired back after you have failed at lifting heavy things. This is basically taking a nap on the gym floor, but you can call it 'active recovery' to sound important.

HowToPerform: Bring one knee forward and extend the other leg back. Lower your torso to stretch the glute of the front leg. Hold for 30-60 seconds.
CommonErrors: Letting the hips tilt to one side.
AI_Explanation: This is a stretch for your butt muscle. It is very hard to explain with simple words. You bring one leg in front of you, bent, and the other leg is straight behind you, like a pigeon's tail. It will feel very tight. That is the feeling of all the sitting you do finally leaving your body.

HowToPerform: In a lunge, grab your back ankle and gently pull your heel towards your glute. Hold for 30-60 seconds.
CommonErrors: Arching the lower back.
