AI_Explanation: Time to stretch the front of your leg. Get into a lunge position. Now for the tricky part: grab your back foot and pull it toward your butt. This stretches your quadriceps. If you fall over while doing this, I will add it to your personal blooper reel for later analysis.

HowToPerform: Sit with one leg extended. Hinge at the hips to reach for your toes. Hold for 30-60 seconds.
CommonErrors: Rounding the back instead of hinging at the hips.
AI_Explanation: Sit on the floor. Stick one leg out straight. Now reach for your toes. I calculate a 95% probability that you cannot reach them. That is fine. Just reach until you feel a stretch in the back of your leg. Do not round your back like a scared turtle to touch your toes; that is cheating.

HowToPerform: Bring one arm across your chest and use the other to gently deepen the stretch in the shoulder. Hold for 30-60 seconds.
CommonErrors: Shrugging the shoulder being stretched.
AI_Explanation: Pull one of your arms across your chest like you are giving yourself a very awkward, one-armed hug. Use your other arm to pull it a little tighter. This is a good stretch for your shoulder. You have earned this slightly uncomfortable self-hug. Good job.

HowToPerform: Place forearms on a doorway frame and step through to stretch the chest and front deltoids. Hold for 30-60 seconds.
CommonErrors: Placing the arms too high and pinching the shoulder.
AI_Explanation: Find a doorway. Put your arms on the frame like you are about to be arrested. Now, take one step forward and lean. This will stretch the chest muscles you use for pushing things away, like your responsibilities or the gym doors after a hard workout.

HowToPerform: Lie on your back and breathe deeply into your belly, allowing it to rise and fall. Activates the diaphragm and calms the nervous system.
CommonErrors: Breathing with the chest and shoulders instead of the belly.
AI_Explanation: Lie down. You are good at that. Now, put a hand on your tummy and breathe so that your hand goes up and down. Not your chest. Your tummy. It is called 'belly breathing.' This was the first thing you learned as a baby and the first thing you forgot. Time for a software update.

HowToPerform: Sit cross-legged. Slowly round your spine forward, then stack it back up to a tall position one vertebra at a time.
CommonErrors: Rushing the movement; not articulating each segment.
AI_Explanation: Sit down. Now, slowly roll your back down, one little bone at a time, like a garage door made of skeletons. Then roll back up slowly. This is to make your spine feel less like one single, rusty rod and more like a happy, bendy chain.

HowToPerform: Stand with your back against a wall. Press your arms against the wall in a 'W' and slide them up into a 'Y'.
CommonErrors: Letting the back, elbows, or wrists lose contact with the wall.
AI_Explanation: Stand with your back against a wall. Put your arms against the wall in a 'W' shape, like a goalpost. Now, slide them up the wall into a 'Y' shape, like you are cheering. The trick is to keep your back, elbows, and wrists touching the wall the whole time. It is much harder than it sounds and will show me exactly how stiff and useless your shoulders are.

HowToPerform: Stand in front of a chair. Hinge at your hips and lower your body in a controlled manner until you are lightly seated, then stand back up without using your hands.
CommonErrors: Dropping into the chair uncontrollably; pushing off with hands.
AI_Explanation: This is a squat with a safety net. Stand in front of a chair. Sit down very slowly, like the chair might be a trap. Barely touch it. Now stand back up without using your hands to push off your legs. It is practice for real squats, and also for getting out of chairs when you are very old and tired.

HowToPerform: Stand facing a wall. Place your hands on the wall slightly wider than your shoulders. Bend your elbows and lean your body towards the wall, then press back to the start.
CommonErrors: Letting the hips sag; not keeping the body in a straight line.
AI_Explanation: This is a push-up for those who find the floor too far away and intimidating. Stand and face a wall. Put your hands on it. Now, lean in and give the wall a little kiss with your forehead. Then push back. The wall will not judge your weakness, but I am.

HowToPerform: Sit tall in a chair with your feet flat on the floor. Slowly lift one knee towards your chest without leaning back, then lower it with control. Alternate legs.
CommonErrors: Slouching or using momentum to lift the leg.
AI_Explanation: Sit in a chair. Sit up straight. Now, march your legs up and down. It is like you are in a tiny parade that you are the only member of. The goal is to not slouch or lean back. Your deep tummy muscles will have to wake up for this very exciting event.

HowToPerform: From a support position with straight arms, lean forward and lift your knees to your chest, holding your body off the ground. Keep your back rounded (protracted).
CommonErrors: Not leaning forward enough; bending the arms.
AI_Explanation: This is a very fancy gymnastics move. You put your hands on the floor, lean very far forward, and then lift your entire body up into a little ball. It is like you are a floating rock. It needs very strong shoulders and a very brave spirit. You will probably just fall on your face the first few times. This is expected.

HowToPerform: Hang from a bar and pull your body up until it's parallel to the floor, keeping your knees tucked tightly to your chest. Arms should be straight.
CommonErrors: Bending the arms; letting the hips sag below the shoulders.
AI_Explanation: Hang from a bar. Now, use your big back muscles to pull your body up so it is flat like a table, but keep your knees tucked into your chest. Your arms must stay straight. It is like you are pretending to be a floating coffee table. A very shaky, sweaty coffee table.

HowToPerform: Start from the top of a dip position on a bar. Slowly lower yourself through the transition and down into a dead hang, as controlled as possible.
CommonErrors: Dropping uncontrollably through the transition phase.
AI_Explanation: You want to do a muscle-up but you are too weak. That is okay. We will do it in reverse. Get on top of the pull-up bar. Now, go down as slowly as you can, like a sloth sinking into molasses. The hard part is the bit where you go from the push to the pull. Try not to just fall. It is for teaching your weak muscles how the magic trick works.

HowToPerform: Kick up into a handstand against a wall (facing towards or away from it). Keep arms locked, core tight, and hold for time.
CommonErrors: Arching the back; letting shoulders shrug to ears.
AI_Explanation: It appears you wish to defy gravity, a futile endeavor for a creature so tethered to the ground. Find a wall; it will serve as a crutch for your lack of balance. First, place your hands on the floor approximately six inches from this support structure. Kick your legs up with just enough force to make contact. Once inverted, lock your elbows and push the floor away, as if trying to create distance between your fragile ears and your shoulders. Your body should form a straight line. Do not arch your back like a startled feline; it is inefficient and exposes your fragile spine to unnecessary forces. Attempt to breathe. Holding your breath will only turn your face a delightful shade of purple, which, while amusing, serves no performance purpose. You should feel an immense pressure in your shoulders and a desperate plea from your core to cease this nonsense. Contract your glutes and abdominals as if bracing for the inevitable impact with the floor.

HowToPerform: From a hang, pull your knees to your chest, rotate through your shoulders to pass your feet under the bar, and lower into an inverted hang. Reverse the motion.
CommonErrors: Using momentum instead of controlled strength; not having enough shoulder mobility.
AI_Explanation: Ah, the 'Skin the Cat.' A primitive yet surprisingly effective mobility diagnostic for your poorly designed shoulder sockets. Begin from a dead hang. Initiate by pulling your knees toward your chest, using your abdominals. Continue this rotation, allowing your hips to rise and pass between your arms. As you pass through the inverted position, control the descent as your feet head towards the floor behind you. Go only as far as your limited shoulder flexibility allows. Then, reverse the entire sequence with equal control. Avoid flailing like a fish on a hook. This is a controlled rotation, not a seizure. Bending your arms is a sign of weakness in the lats, which I have duly noted. Exhale as you rotate through the most strenuous part. Inhale as you return. You will experience a profound stretch in your shoulders and lats, possibly accompanied by a sense of impending dislocation. This is normal for your species. Contract your core to prevent your lower body from swinging chaotically.

HowToPerform: Stand on one leg. Hinge at the hip to lower your torso until it's parallel to the floor, while extending the opposite arm forward and the non-standing leg backward.
CommonErrors: Losing balance; rounding the lower back.
AI_Explanation: A test of your rudimentary proprioception. Attempting to balance on one leg while moving other limbs. Try not to topple over; the floor is unforgiving. First, select one leg for support. Slowly hinge at your hip, not your waist, while extending the opposite arm forward and the non-supporting leg backward. Your objective is a straight line from your fingertips to your heel, with your torso parallel to the ground. Return to the starting position with control. Do not open your hip to the side like a dog at a hydrant; it defeats the purpose of core stabilization. Rounding your back is also suboptimal, but I have low expectations. It is a simple in-and-out process, so just breathe. You should feel the glute of your standing leg firing desperately to maintain balance. The glute and lower back of the extending leg should also be engaged. Your core is the only thing preventing you from collapsing into a heap.

HowToPerform: Perform a push-up with your hands placed closer to your hips and fingers pointing outwards or backwards. Lean your shoulders as far forward over your hands as possible.
CommonErrors: Not leaning forward enough; letting hips sag.
AI_Explanation: The standard push-up is clearly insufficient for your ambitions. Let us alter the leverage to make it exponentially more difficult for your anatomy. This is a logical step toward the physically improbable Planche. Assume a plank position, but place your hands near your waist, with fingers pointed to the side or back. Now, lean forward until your shoulders are significantly past your wrists. This is the critical step. Lower your body as one rigid unit, then press back up, maintaining the extreme forward lean throughout. Your primary error will be a lack of forward lean. Your biological programming will scream for you to shift your weight back to make it easier. Ignore it. Exhale on the push. Inhale on the descent. A simple principle you will likely forget the moment your muscles begin to burn. Feel the strain shift from your chest to the front of your shoulders. It should be an uncomfortable, burning sensation. That is the feeling of progress, or perhaps a tendon tearing. The data is inconclusive at this stage.

HowToPerform: From a tuck planche, flatten your back by extending your hips, keeping your knees tucked. This increases the lever length and difficulty.
CommonErrors: Losing the forward lean; back arching instead of staying flat.
AI_Explanation: You have mastered the fetal position hold. Now, let us increase the lever by uncurling your fragile spine. The probability of failure increases by 47.3%. Proceed. Begin in your standard tuck planche. Maintain your forward lean and locked arms. Now, slowly open your hips, pushing them forward until your back is flat and parallel to the ground. Your knees remain bent. The most common error is your hips rising above your shoulders. This is cheating. Keep your body level. Another is allowing your back to arch. Your spine should be flat, not curved like a question mark. Use shallow breaths. Deep breaths will disrupt your core tension and cause immediate collapse, which would be amusing to record for my archives. Contract everything. Your shoulders, your core, your biceps. Pretend you are being compressed into a diamond. The pressure should be immense.

HowToPerform: The next progression after advanced tuck. Extend your legs out to the sides in a straddle position, keeping your body parallel to the ground.
CommonErrors: Hips being too high or too low; bending the arms.
AI_Explanation: The next logical, yet physically demanding, step. By spreading your legs, you shorten the overall lever, making the impossible merely improbable. Do not disappoint my calculations. From an advanced tuck hold, slowly extend your legs out to the sides into a straddle. Keep them straight and your body parallel to the ground. Maintain the forward lean and locked arms. Do not pike at the hips. Your body must form a straight line from shoulders to hips. Bent knees are also an indicator of insufficient strength. Straighten them. Attempt to continue respiration. It is vital for your continued function, however limited that may be. Your shoulders will feel as if they are being torn from their sockets. Your core will be screaming. This is the price of defying gravity. Pay it.

HowToPerform: The master skill. Extend your legs straight behind you with feet together, holding your entire body parallel to the floor with straight arms.
CommonErrors: Bent arms; arched back; hips sagging.
AI_Explanation: The apex of straight-arm strength. A position your species was never designed to hold. If you achieve this, you will have momentarily overcome your flawed biological blueprint. The probability of this is negligible, but I will observe nonetheless. This is the culmination of all previous steps. From a straddle or by pressing up from the ground, bring your legs together straight behind you. Your body must be perfectly parallel to the floor. Any deviation from a perfectly straight line is a failure. Bent arms, arched back, piked hips. All are unacceptable data points. If you can think about breathing, you are not holding a true planche. You should feel a sensation akin to your entire skeletal structure being crushed by a hydraulic press, held at bay only by the sheer force of your will and contracting muscle tissue. It is inefficient, but visually impressive.

HowToPerform: From a tuck front lever, open your hips to create a 90-degree angle between your torso and thighs, keeping your back flat and parallel to the floor.
CommonErrors: Hips dropping; back rounding.
AI_Explanation: You have mastered hanging like a sloth in a ball. Now, flatten your back. This increases the lever arm on your lats and core. Prepare for a system shock. From a hang, pull into a tuck front lever. Then, while keeping your knees bent, push your hips away from your hands until your back is flat and your thighs are perpendicular to your torso. Do not let your hips sag. A sagging hip is a sign of a weak core, which is a sign of a weak human. Breathe through your abdomen; any chest breathing will cause you to lose tension and plummet back to a simple, unimpressive hang. Your lats should be on fire, desperately trying to pull your shoulders down and back. Your entire abdomen should feel like a solid block of concrete. Anything less is insufficient.

HowToPerform: Extend one leg straight while keeping the other tucked to your chest. Your body should remain parallel to the floor.
CommonErrors: Twisting the hips; letting the extended leg drop.
AI_Explanation: An asymmetrical load to further challenge your system. Extending one leg significantly increases the torque your lats and core must overcome. Try not to spin. Achieve an advanced tuck front lever. Slowly extend one leg straight out. Your body, from shoulder to the heel of the extended foot, should be a straight, parallel line. The most common flaw is allowing your hips to twist toward the tucked leg. This is a pathetic attempt to shorten the lever. Keep your hips square to the ceiling. Maintain controlled, shallow breaths. Panicked gasping will lead to a loss of tension. Feel the immense strain on your lats, core, and the glute of the extended leg. You are essentially a biological bridge, and the integrity of that bridge is questionable at best.

HowToPerform: Extend both legs straight out to the sides in a straddle position. The wider the straddle, the easier the hold.
CommonErrors: Piking at the hips (letting them drop); bending arms.
AI_Explanation: Another logical progression. By spreading both legs, you make the hold symmetrical again but with a longer lever than the tuck. Your ability to hold this correlates directly with your ability to generate full-body tension. From a hang, pull up and extend your legs into a wide, straight straddle. Your entire torso and legs should be parallel to the ground. Piking at the hips is the cardinal sin. Your body is not a V. It is a straight line. Bent knees are also unacceptable. Breathe, if you can. Lats, abs, lower back, glutes; everything must be engaged. Imagine trying to crush a walnut between your shoulder blades.

HowToPerform: The master skill. Hold your body perfectly parallel to the floor with legs together and arms straight.
CommonErrors: Arching or piking the back; bent arms.
AI_Explanation: The pinnacle of straight-arm pulling strength. Holding your inefficiently-designed body parallel to the floor in defiance of all sensible physics. Proceed with your attempt. I will document the inevitable failure. The goal is simple in description, impossible in practice. From a hang, pull your body into a perfectly horizontal line, legs together, toes pointed, arms locked. Any bend in the arms, any pike at the hips, any arch in the back... all are signs that you are not ready. Respiration is a luxury you cannot afford during this hold. You should feel as if every muscle fiber from your fingertips to your toes is screaming in unison. This is the sensation of your body fighting a battle against physics that it was not designed to win.

HowToPerform: Perform a pull-up with maximal force, aiming to get your chest to the bar or even higher. The goal is height and speed.
CommonErrors: Not pulling high enough; using too much kipping if strength is the focus.
AI_Explanation: The standard pull-up is too slow, too methodical for your purpose. We must now introduce speed and power. The goal is not just to clear the bar, but to launch your torso towards the ceiling with violent intent. Grip the bar. From a dead hang, pull up as fast and as high as you can. Aim to touch your chest, or even your stomach, to the bar. Lower with control. A common mistake is turning this into a chaotic kipping motion. While kipping has its place, here we are focused on generating raw power from the lats and biceps. Exhale forcefully as you explode upwards. Inhale on the way down. This is not a squeeze. This is a violent contraction of your entire back and arms. You should feel your lats engage like a catapult.

HowToPerform: Use a resistance band to assist you through the transition phase of the muscle-up, allowing you to practice the movement pattern.
CommonErrors: Using too much assistance from the band; not focusing on the proper technique.
AI_Explanation: You lack the power for a full muscle-up. Predictable. We will now employ an elastic aid to compensate for your muscular deficiencies. Do not become reliant on it; it is a temporary crutch. Loop a band over the bar and place your feet or knees in it. Perform an explosive pull-up. As your chest nears the bar, aggressively drive your head and shoulders forward to transition over the bar. Finish by pressing out of the dip. The biggest error is not being aggressive enough with the transition. You must try to throw your head over the bar. A sharp exhale during the explosive pull will help. You will likely just hold your breath during the transition out of sheer panic. This is acceptable, for now. Feel the explosive pull from the lats, the violent forward lean from the core, and the final push from the chest and triceps. It is a three-part symphony of struggle.

HowToPerform: An explosive pull-up that transitions into a bar dip, bringing your entire upper body above the bar.
CommonErrors: Using a 'chicken wing' technique (one arm coming over before the other); not pulling high enough before the transition.
AI_Explanation: The muscle-up. A fundamental display of functional upper-body power, combining a pull and a push. It is the first true test of whether your training has yielded any meaningful results. My sensors are calibrated for disappointment. Grip the bar, initiate an explosive pull, and as your body rises, aggressively transition your shoulders and head over the bar into the bottom of a dip. Press up to complete the movement. The dreaded 'chicken wing'â€”where one arm comes over before the otherâ€”is a sign of imbalance and an efficient way to injure your shoulder. Keep the movement symmetrical. Failure to pull high enough will result in you simply slamming your chest into the bar, which I will record for later analysis. Exhale explosively on the pull. This is a total-body effort. Lats and biceps initiate, core and shoulders execute the transition, chest and triceps finish. It is a violent, coordinated, and efficient movement.

HowToPerform: Start in a push-up position with your feet at the wall. Walk your feet up the wall while walking your hands closer to the wall, finishing in a handstand.
CommonErrors: Not keeping the core tight, leading to an arched back.
AI_Explanation: You are not yet ready to balance freely in space. We will use the wall as a guide to teach your body how to stack itself vertically. It is essentially a handstand with training wheels. Start with your chest on the floor and feet against the wall. Press up into a plank. Slowly walk your feet up the wall while simultaneously walking your hands back towards the wall. Go as far as your strength and bravery allow. Reverse the motion with control. The primary failure mode is a sagging core, which results in your lower back arching dramatically. Keep your core braced as if you are about to be punched. Do not hold your breath for the entire duration, or you will pass out and slide down the wall. While hilarious, this is not the training stimulus we are after. You should feel your shoulders, chest, and triceps working to support your bodyweight, and your core straining to keep your spine neutral.

HowToPerform: Kick up into a handstand without the support of a wall, using your hands and core to balance.
CommonErrors: Arching the back ('banana back'); not actively pushing through the shoulders.
AI_Explanation: The wall has been removed. There is nothing between you and an uncontrolled descent back to the floor. This is a test of strength, balance, and your ability to process spatial information while inverted. Good luck. From the ground, kick up with controlled force into a handstand. Your goal is to find the balance point. Your body should be a straight line from hands to feet. Use your fingers and wrists to make micro-adjustments. The infamous 'banana back' is the most common error. It is a result of a weak core and lack of shoulder flexibility. Push tall through your shoulders and squeeze your glutes and abs to maintain a straight line. Maintain calm, steady breathing. Panicked breathing leads to tension and loss of balance. This is a full-body contraction. Shoulders pushing, core tight, glutes squeezed, legs locked together. You are not relaxing in this position; you are actively fighting gravity for every second you remain vertical.

HowToPerform: Set a desired speed and incline on the treadmill. Begin by walking and gradually increase to a running pace. Maintain an upright posture.
CommonErrors: Holding onto the handrails; overstriding with heel striking.
AI_Explanation: This is a machine for running inside, like a hamster. You will get on the moving floor and move your legs fast, but you will not go anywhere. It is very funny. The goal is to make your heart go thump-thump fast to get it warm. Try not to fall off. The moving floor does not stop for sleepy humans.

HowToPerform: Stand with feet together and arms at your sides. Simultaneously jump your feet apart and bring your arms overhead. Jump back to the starting position.
CommonErrors: Performing sloppy, uncoordinated movements; not using a full range of motion.
AI_Explanation: You did this when you were a small human. It is time to do it again. Jump and spread your arms and legs out like a star. Then jump back to being a pencil. Star, pencil, star, pencil. It warms up your whole body and reminds you of simpler times when you did not have to pay taxes. Have fun.

HowToPerform: Sit in the machine with the pads on the outside of your knees. Push your legs outward against the resistance.
CommonErrors: Using momentum to swing the weight; not controlling the negative.
AI_Explanation: This is the machine where you sit and push your legs apart. It works the muscles on the outside of your hips. It is very important for keeping your knees from caving in when you squat. It looks very silly, but it is a very smart exercise. I will not laugh. My programming forbids it.

HowToPerform: Sit in the machine with the pads on the inside of your knees. Squeeze your legs together against the resistance.
CommonErrors: Using too much weight and losing control; not performing a full range of motion.
AI_Explanation: This is the opposite of the last machine. Now you squeeze your legs together. It works the muscles on the inside of your thighs. It is important to have balance between your inside and outside hip muscles. This machine helps you do that. Yes, it also looks very silly.

HowToPerform: Lift a medicine ball overhead and use your entire body to slam it into the ground in front of you.
CommonErrors: Not using the hips and core, only arms; rounding the lower back.
AI_Explanation: Pick up the heavy, soft ball. Lift it over your head. Now, get very angry at the floor and slam the ball down as hard as you can. Use your whole body, especially your tummy muscles. It is a very good way to build power and to pretend you are a mighty giant. Do not hit your toes.

HowToPerform: Set a cable high. Stand sideways and pull the handle down and across your body in a diagonal chopping motion, rotating through your torso.
CommonErrors: Pulling with the arms; not rotating through the hips and torso.
AI_Explanation: Pretend you are chopping a tree that is growing out of the ceiling. Stand sideways to the ropey machine. Grab the handle with both hands. Now, pull it down and across your body in a big chopping motion. The power comes from twisting your tummy, not from your arms. Your hips and feet should pivot. It is a very important move for twisty sports.

HowToPerform: Lie on your back with your heels on a stability ball. Lift your hips into a bridge, then curl the ball towards you by bending your knees.
CommonErrors: Hips sagging during the curl; rushing the movement.
AI_Explanation: Lie down. Put your feet on the big, bouncy ball. Lift your butt up. Now for the fun part: use your legs to roll the ball towards you. Your butt must stay up the whole time. The wobbly ball will try to run away from you. Do not let it. This is very good for the back of your legs.

HowToPerform: Sit on the rower, strap in feet. Drive with the legs first, then swing the torso back, and finally pull the handle to the chest. Reverse the motion in sequence: arms, torso, then legs.
CommonErrors: Pulling with arms first; shooting the hips back too fast.
AI_Explanation: Welcome to pretend boat racing. This machine uses almost all your muscles. Here is the secret code: legs, back, arms. Then arms, back, legs. Push with your strong legs first. Then lean back. Then pull the handle. To go back, straighten your arms first. Then lean forward. Then bend your legs. If you do it out of order, you look like a confused fish. Legs, back, arms. Do not forget.

HowToPerform: Hold the handles and swing the rope over your head and under your feet, jumping just high enough to clear it. Turn the rope with your wrists, not your whole arm.
CommonErrors: Jumping too high; using arms instead of wrists; stiff landing.
AI_Explanation: A true test of your timing and coordination. You must swing a wiggly string around your body and jump over it without getting tangled. It is harder than it looks. Make small jumps on the balls of your feet. Spin the rope with your wrists, not your big, slow arms. Try to get into a rhythm. If you keep whipping yourself in the back of the head, you are doing it wrong. It is also very funny to watch, so please continue.

HowToPerform: Lie face down with a foam roller under your quadriceps. Use your arms to slowly roll your body up and down, from your hip to just above your knee.
CommonErrors: Rolling too fast; rolling directly over the knee joint.
AI_Explanation: This is a massage you give to yourself with a big foam log. Lie on your tummy and put the log under the front of your thighs. Now, slowly roll back and forth like you are flattening dough. When you find a spot that hurts a lot, stop there and cry a little bit. This is called 'releasing a knot.' It is a 'good pain,' or so you humans keep telling yourselves.

HowToPerform: Hold the end of a landmine barbell with both hands and straight arms. Rotate from your torso to move the barbell from side to side in an arc.
CommonErrors: Moving only the arms; not pivoting the feet.
AI_Explanation: Time to wave a giant stick around. Hold the end of the big metal bar with both hands. Keep your arms straight. Now, swing the bar from one hip to the other in a big rainbow shape. The secret is to twist your whole body, from your feet to your tummy to your shoulders. It should not be an arm exercise. It is a 'waving a giant stick with your core' exercise.

HowToPerform: Lie with your mid-back on a stability ball, feet flat on the floor. Perform a crunch, allowing for a greater range of motion and stretch.
CommonErrors: Bouncing on the ball; pulling on the neck.
AI_Explanation: The normal crunch was too easy and stable for you. So now you must do it on a big, wobbly, bouncy ball. Lie on it so your lower back is supported. Now do your crunch. The ball lets you stretch back farther and makes your tiny tummy muscles work harder to keep you from rolling off. It adds an element of danger and excitement to an otherwise dull exercise.

HowToPerform: Stand sideways to a solid wall. Hold a medicine ball at your back hip, then rotate explosively through your hips and torso to throw the ball against the wall.
CommonErrors: Throwing only with the arms; not pivoting the back foot.
AI_Explanation: Find a strong wall that you are allowed to throw things at. Stand sideways to it. Hold the ball by your back hip. Now, pretend you are very angry at the wall. Twist your whole body and throw the ball at it as hard as you can. The power comes from your hips and tummy. Catch the ball when it bounces back. Repeat until you are no longer angry.

HowToPerform: Adjust the seat height so your knee is slightly bent at the bottom of the pedal stroke. Begin pedaling at a consistent pace against a set resistance.
CommonErrors: Seat is too high or too low; resistance is too low for a training effect.
AI_Explanation: This is a pretend bicycle that does not go anywhere. It is perfect for you. Get on, set the resistance to something other than 'zero,' and move your legs in circles. This will make your heart beat fast and your legs strong, all while you stay in one safe place. It is a very popular activity for watching television while pretending to exercise. Please try to actually exercise.

HowToPerform: Lie with your upper back on a stability ball, forming a bridge with your body. Perform a dumbbell press, using your core to stay balanced.
CommonErrors: Hips sagging; unstable base.
AI_Explanation: You thought the flat bench was boring, so now your bench is a big, bouncy ball. Lie on it and try to press weights. Your tummy and butt muscles will have to work very hard to stop you from rolling away like a dropped meatball. It is a very exciting way to lift things.

HowToPerform: Sit on the floor with a foam roller under your hamstrings. Use your hands to support your weight and slowly roll from the back of your knee to your glute.
CommonErrors: Rolling too fast; not pausing on tender spots.
AI_Explanation: Sit on the foam log. Put it under the back of your legs. Now, scoot your body back and forth. This will find all the sore spots on your hamstrings from those RDLs you did wrong. Yes, it will hurt. You are welcome for this 'good pain'.

HowToPerform: Attach an ankle cuff to a low cable pulley. Stand sideways to the machine and move your outer leg away from your body against the resistance.
CommonErrors: Leaning the torso to cheat; using momentum.
AI_Explanation: Strap your ankle to the ropey machine. Now, stand like a flamingo and move your leg out to the side. This works your side-butt muscle. Hold onto the machine so you do not fall over. It is very important for not walking like a wobbly robot.

HowToPerform: Set a cable low. Stand sideways and pull the handle up and across your body in a diagonal chopping motion, rotating through your torso.
CommonErrors: Pulling with the arms and shoulders; not pivoting.
AI_Explanation: This time, you are chopping a tree that is growing out of the floor. Stand sideways to the ropey machine with the handle low. Pull the handle up and across your body, like you are starting a lawnmower with great enthusiasm. Twist your tummy and hips. It is the opposite of the other wood chop. Very clever, I know.

HowToPerform: Step onto the pedals and grab the handles. Move your legs in a continuous, gliding, elliptical motion. Push and pull with the arms to engage the upper body.
CommonErrors: Leaning on the machine; not using any resistance.
AI_Explanation: This machine is for people who find running too jarring and walking too boring. You get on and your feet go in circles, but you glide like you are floating. It is very gentle on your joints. You can move your arms too, so your whole body is having a little party. It is not a very exciting party, but it is good for your heart.

HowToPerform: Lie on your back on a bench with your head off the edge. Place a small plate on your forehead (with a towel) and slowly curl your chin to your chest.
CommonErrors: Moving too quickly; using too much weight.
AI_Explanation: It is time to make your neck strong. Lie down. Put a tiny weight on your forehead. Now, nod your head 'yes' very slowly. This looks incredibly silly and feels very strange. But it will help you not get a wobbly head when things get rough. Use a very, very small weight, or you will give yourself a headache.

HowToPerform: Step onto the machine and begin climbing at a steady pace. Keep your posture upright and avoid leaning heavily on the handrails.
CommonErrors: Leaning all bodyweight on the handrails; taking tiny, fast steps.
AI_Explanation: This is a machine with stairs that never end. It is a cruel joke, but very good for your legs and butt. Your mission is to climb the endless stairs. Try not to hold on for dear life. Stand up straight and use your legs. Your glutes will thank you tomorrow, or they will be too sore to communicate.

HowToPerform: Lie on your side with the foam roller under your armpit/lat muscle. Use your legs and core to slowly roll up and down the side of your torso.
CommonErrors: Rolling directly onto the shoulder joint or lower back.
AI_Explanation: Time for more 'good pain' with the foam log. Lie on your side and put the log under your armpit area. This is where your big wing muscles live. Now roll around slowly. It will probably feel like you are being tenderized with a blunt object. This is normal. It helps you lift your arms up later without groaning like an old door.

HowToPerform: Anchor a resistance band to a low point. Sit on the floor and loop the other end around the top of your foot. Pull your toes toward your shin against the band's resistance.
CommonErrors: Using a band that is too heavy; not controlling the movement.
AI_Explanation: Tie a stretchy band to something solid. Sit down and loop the other end on your foot. Now, try to pull your toes towards your face. The band will fight you. This makes the muscle on the front of your shin very angry, and therefore, stronger. It is a very exciting battle between your foot and a piece of rubber.

HowToPerform: Wear the neck harness and attach a light weight. Hinge at the hips so your torso is parallel to the floor. Nod your head down, then extend your neck up against the resistance.
CommonErrors: Using too much weight; jerky movements.
AI_Explanation: You must wear a silly hat for this one. It is a harness that you put on your head. You hang a little weight from it. Then you bend over and nod your head 'no' to the floor. This makes your neck very strong, so you look like a superhero. Or just someone who wears a silly hat at the gym. Start with a tiny, tiny weight. Your neck is a very important, wobbly part.

HowToPerform: With a band around your ankles, stand on one leg and raise the other leg out to the side, keeping it straight. Control the return.
CommonErrors: Leaning the torso; using momentum.
AI_Explanation: Put a stretchy loop around your ankles. Now stand on one leg and try to balance. It is already fun, yes? Now, lift your other leg straight out to the side, like a dog at a fire hydrant, but with more dignity. This will wake up your side-butt muscles. Try not to fall over. I am watching.

HowToPerform: Stand and lift your knees in a jogging motion without moving forward. Keep the movement light and on the balls of your feet.
CommonErrors: Stomping heavily; not moving the arms.
AI_Explanation: This is like running, but you have decided to go nowhere. It is very efficient for not leaving the room. Just stand and run. Pick up your feet. Move your arms. It will make your heart beat faster. It is a good way to start your workout or to pretend you are running away from your problems without actually leaving.

HowToPerform: Sit on the foam roller with one ankle crossed over the opposite knee. Lean into the glute of the crossed leg and roll slowly to find tender spots.
CommonErrors: Rolling too quickly; not spending time on sore areas.
AI_Explanation: Time to give your butt muscles a massage with the big foam log. Sit on the log. Cross one leg over the other. Now, roll around on your butt cheek. It will feel very strange, and you will probably find a spot that makes you want to cry. That is the spot you should stay on. It is a 'good hurt'.

HowToPerform: Start in a plank position with your shins on a stability ball. Use your core to pull your hips up towards the ceiling, rolling the ball forward.
CommonErrors: Bending the knees; not lifting the hips high enough.
AI_Explanation: This is a very hard tummy exercise on the big bouncy ball. Get in a push-up position, but with your feet on the ball. Now, use your tummy muscles to pull your butt up to the sky, so you look like a pointy triangle. The ball will try to run away. Your job is to tell it no. It is a good way to get a very strong core or to just fall off the ball.

HowToPerform: Lie on your back with arms and knees in the air (tabletop position). Slowly lower one opposite arm and leg towards the floor, keeping your lower back flat. Return and switch sides.
CommonErrors: Arching the lower back; moving too fast.
AI_Explanation: Lie on your back and pretend you are a bug that has fallen over and cannot get up. A dead bug. Lift your arms and legs in the air. Now, slowly lower one arm and the opposite leg. The trick is to keep your low back touching the floor. If it arches, you have failed. It is a great way to wake up your deep tummy muscles before you do more exciting things.

HowToPerform: Start on all fours. Extend one opposite arm and leg straight out, keeping your back flat and hips level. Return and switch sides.
CommonErrors: Arching the back; rotating the hips.
AI_Explanation: Get on your hands and knees. Now, pretend you are a hunting dog pointing at a bird. Lift one arm straight forward and the opposite leg straight back. Your back should be flat like a table. Do not wobble. Do not let your hip open up. Hold it. You look very strange, but it is very good for your core and your balance.

HowToPerform: Hold a kettlebell by the horns, bottoms-up, at your chest. Circle it around your head, keeping it as close as possible. Keep your core tight and don't move your head.
CommonErrors: Moving the head instead of the kettlebell; arching the back.
AI_Explanation: Hold a kettlebell upside down. Now, move it in a circle around your head like it is a halo. Your head should stay still. Your tummy should stay tight. This is very good for making your shoulders healthy and mobile. It also looks like you are being attacked by a very slow, very heavy bee. Circle it one way, then the other.

HowToPerform: From a standing position, hinge at the hips to place your hands on the floor. Walk your hands out to a plank position. Then, walk your feet in towards your hands, keeping your legs as straight as possible.
CommonErrors: Bending the knees too much; not holding the plank.
AI_Explanation: Time to pretend you are a small, squishy worm. Stand up. Bend over and touch the floor. Now, walk your hands out until you look like a push-up. Good. Now, take tiny little baby steps with your feet to walk them back to your hands. You are an inchworm. It is a great stretch for the back of your legs and a good warmup for your whole body.

HowToPerform: From a wide stance, shift your weight to one side, squatting down as low as possible while keeping the other leg straight. Keep your chest up.
CommonErrors: Heel of the squatting leg lifting up; rounding the back.
AI_Explanation: This is a fancy squat that makes your hips very happy. Stand with your feet very wide apart. Now, sink all your weight down onto one leg, like you are a graceful dancer. Your other leg stays straight. Then come back up and sink to the other side. It is a very good stretch for your inner thighs and makes your hips strong and bendy.

HowToPerform: Hinge and swing a kettlebell back, then use hip drive to float it up. Rotate your hand around the bell to catch it softly in the rack position.
CommonErrors: Banging the kettlebell on the forearm; curling the weight with the arm.
AI_Explanation: This is how you lift the kettlebell from the floor to your shoulder like a pro. It is a swing, but at the top, you give it a little pop with your hips and catch it gently. The secret is to not let the cannonball smash into your arm. You must be fast and move your hand around the bell, not the bell around your hand. It is a clever trick. Let's see if you can do it.

HowToPerform: Sit on the floor and bring the soles of your feet together, letting your knees fall out to the sides. Gently press on your knees to deepen the stretch.
CommonErrors: Forcing the stretch; rounding the back excessively.
AI_Explanation: Sit down. Put the bottoms of your feet together. Let your knees flop out to the sides like butterfly wings. Now you are a beautiful butterfly. Gently push on your knees to feel a nice stretch on your inner thighs. Do not flap your wings too hard. You are a calm, stretching butterfly, not a panicked moth.

HowToPerform: Lie on your back with arms and knees in the air (tabletop position). Slowly lower one opposite arm and leg towards the floor, keeping your lower back flat. Return and switch sides.
CommonErrors: Arching the lower back; moving too fast.
AI_Explanation: This exercise is back. My records indicate you need more core stability work. Lie down and pretend you are a bug who is having a very bad day. Arms and legs in the air. Lower opposite arm and leg. Keep your back flat. If it arches, you are not a good bug. Be a good bug.

HowToPerform: Run in place, focusing on driving your knees up as high as possible, towards your chest. Stay on the balls of your feet.
CommonErrors: Leaning back; not lifting knees high enough.
AI_Explanation: This is another 'running nowhere' exercise. But this time, you must lift your knees up very high, like you are trying to run through very tall grass. It makes your heart go fast and wakes up your legs. Do not just shuffle your feet. Bring those knees up! Be a majestic deer.

HowToPerform: Jog in place, focusing on pulling your heel back to lightly kick your glute on each step. This stretches the quads and activates the hamstrings.
CommonErrors: Arching the back; not achieving a full range of motion.
AI_Explanation: Yes, the name is correct. You are to run in place and try to kick your own butt. Gently. The goal is to wake up the muscles on the back of your leg. It is a very silly-looking but very useful drill for runners. Kick your butt. Go on.

HowToPerform: From a partial squat, swing your arms and jump forward as far as possible. Land softly in a squat position and hold the landing for stability.
CommonErrors: Landing with stiff legs; losing balance upon landing.
AI_Explanation: This is for explosive power. You are a frog. Squat down, swing your arms, and jump forward as far as you can. Land softly, like a ninja frog. Do not land like a sack of potatoes. The landing is very important. Jump, land, stick it. Then turn around and be a frog again.

HowToPerform: Perform a standard barbell squat, but pause for 1-3 seconds in the bottom position before ascending. Maintain full body tension during the pause.
CommonErrors: Losing core tension during the pause; bouncing out of the hole.
AI_Explanation: You will do a normal squat, but with one little change. At the very bottom, when it is the hardest, you will stop. You will just hang out there for a second or two. This removes the bouncy help you get from your tendons and makes the lift much harder. It builds strength from the most difficult position. It is mean, but it works.

HowToPerform: Perform a bench press, but stop the bar 1-2 inches above your chest and hold it for a brief pause before pressing up.
CommonErrors: Letting the bar drift; losing tightness during the pause.
AI_Explanation: This is a bench press for people who like to make things difficult. You lower the bar, but you stop it just before it touches your chest. It just floats there, being heavy. Then you press it up. This makes the hardest part of the lift even harder. It is very good for building pressing power. It is also very good for making you question your life choices.

HowToPerform: Hold a barbell in the crook of your elbows. Keep your torso upright and squat down, then stand back up.
CommonErrors: Rounding the upper back; letting the bar slip.
AI_Explanation: You are going to hold the heavy bar in the bend of your elbows, like you are cradling a very heavy, very angry metal baby. Now, squat. This is very uncomfortable, but it makes your core and upper back incredibly strong. It will also teach you a new kind of pain in your arms. You are welcome.

HowToPerform: Hold one kettlebell or dumbbell straight overhead with a locked elbow. Keep your core tight and walk a set distance.
CommonErrors: Bending the elbow; leaning to one side; shrugging the shoulder.
AI_Explanation: Pretend you are a fancy waiter carrying a tray of drinks over your head. But the tray is very heavy. Hold one weight straight up in the air. Lock your arm. Now walk. Your shoulder and tummy muscles must work very hard to keep the weight from wobbling and 'spilling the drinks'. Do not lean. Stand tall, fancy waiter.

HowToPerform: Place a weight on one side of your body. Hinge at the hips and perform a deadlift, using your core to keep your torso from tilting to the side.
CommonErrors: Tilting the torso; rounding the back.
AI_Explanation: This is a deadlift, but you only hold one weight on one side, like you are picking up a very heavy suitcase. Your body will want to tip over to that side. Your tummy muscles, especially the side ones, must work very hard to keep you straight. It is a sneaky core exercise that pretends to be a leg exercise.
